text: On tap @ Rogue SF. Pours clear pale orange amber with thin white head. Aroma is sugary sweet caramel malt, plenty of bourbon and oak as well. Taste is more of the same. Roasty caramel malt, light bourbon, dry and clean on the finish. This is a pretty much a barleywine, perhaps the lowest abv one around. Bourbon works really well with the base Dead Guy flavor profile.
Pours a bright amber color. Aromas of caramel, malt, and berry. Flavor has a touch of roast toffee taste, some caramel/toffee, and a nice whiskey hints in the finish.

10/5/2011 12:46:58 AM On tap at Beer Temple. Caramel body with a puffy head. Nose is hoppy and quite sour. Sweet and sur notes. Wondering if it might be a bit off as it is really sour and not too much on the malt and caramel side coming through. Got some whisky in there though, quite nice.

Lightly hazed, golden amber color with a diminished taupe head. Interesting aroma of Citrus, bourbon and caramel. Still seems to possess the a clean lager nose. Come unglued in the flavors. A tangled mix of malt, bourbon and hops, that dont seem to like each other. Start is lightly sweet and citric. Middle continues with the citric and just a touch of bourbon. A whiskey on the rocks with a twist flavor. Hints of malt bounce in and out. Things never seem to come together. Some decent flavors that never seem to meet and instead distract. I really wanted to like this one more.

Bottle share. 
Poured into a tulip. Sorry, it wasnt a pilsener glass. I think itll be okay. 
The appearance was a nice looking hazy amber to orange color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute. There wasnt any lacing.
The smell had a nice blend of sweet honey to somewhat tart cherry. 
The taste was mainly sweet and somewhat tart carrying the cherry back into the flavor. Light tart cherry aftertaste leading into a slight bittersweet finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. Theres a nice carbonation about it. 
Overall, I say this was a pretty good Maibock even though I didnt have it in proper glassware. Id still have this again. Maybe recommend with some plain cheesecake.

Copper-amber, clear, thin white head, light lacing
Aroma is of caramel, wood, some light smoke, some fruit
Flavour is lightly sweet, caramel malts, some wood and fruit
Thin mouthfeel, light body, mild carbonation
Finishes sweet, thin.
Not the best, the aroma is much better then anything coming out of the flavour.

this is Dead Guy Ale aged in Dead Guy Whiskey barrels! on tap (but outside-so in a plastic cup). as a frame of reference ive got the ok but passable Dead Guy at 3.1, and the tasty Double Dead Guy at 3.9. This was better than either of those. It was poured cold, but with a thick frothy tan head. smelled great, but mostly malt and earthy hops. not a lot of whisky. super mellow, but flavorful. smooth as hell. id already liked it, but when it started to warm, the whisky came out and played very nicely with the aroma and flavor, while never overpowering the beer. Im not a huge fan of Dead Guy or its siter whiskey by themselves, but apparently together they make a helluva beer."
Disappointing, not much flavor, not rich, and dry at the end. Tried it years ago havent had it since

Aged bottle served in a tulip. Dark honey in color with a large off-white head. Great pour. Good retention and lace. Malty aroma of caramel, toffee, blue cheese, dough, and vanilla. Medium sweet flavor with a light bitterness. Medium body, good carbonation (surprise) and a long orange peel bitter finish. Definitely elements of oak and age, but this one is holding up impressively 3+ years on.

Cheers T-bag! Cloudy medium amber. Fair soapy white head. Aroma is sweet. Caramel. Sweet and fruity, Almost like apple cider in a way. Lighter full body. Moderate to low carbonation. Bready. Biscuit. Some vanilla. Fair woody dryness. No real bitterness. Some sweet bourbon. Barrel character is subdued. This may have been sitting awhile, not sure. Enjoyable, but not as nice as I was expecting.
Malt, caramel, honey, oaky aroma. Taste is similar, fairly sweet, roasty, caramel, malt. smooth, light, a little syrupy in a crisp beer. very nice.

Transfer from BA review on 3-16-12 - 
Served in a 10 oz chalice glass

Appearance  Served a nice light golden orange color with a thin white head. The head was light and faded fast giving way to only a small amount of lacing, but leaving a very persistent layer of wispy foam on the surface of the beer.

Smell  Bourbon is pretty potent in the nose. There are hints of some caramel, juniper, and flowery/earthy hop mixed in with the aroma as well. Quite nice.

Taste  While the nose would have suggested a whole lot of bourbon barrel flavor, it was really quite light. The flavor was a bit more on the side of tart fruit mixed with some carmel flavors. Throughout the taste there are some more spicy flavors. While hard to pinpoint the exact identities they seem to intensify more toward the end and leave an interesting aftertaste in the mouth. Not bad, but not great either, just sorta unique.

Mouthfeel  The body is creamy and the carbonation is rather light. It overall creates a very smooth and easy drinking experience and allows the brew to cling to the tongue.

Overall  This was an interesting beer. It had a rather odd flavor profile in my opinion, kind of random, but nothing was really all that off. Although I dont think I would drink this beer on frequent occasion, it is worth a try.

The candy coated nose full of caramel and toasty malts is hiding at the end in this tasty beer. At first taste you get a salty mix of bitterness and whiskey. As you venture through this beer it mellows out quite nicely as the toasty malt notes in the middle starts to expand into sweet caramel notes that linger in your pallet. I would expect the head to be boring on this beer, other than that, it was well worth the wait and the best of the John Johns....
Pours dark red with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma is whiskey and toasted nuts with some caramel, taste is much the same. Well balanced.

Bottle from Bacchanalia, Cambridge. Poured an amber colour with some floating yeast and a thin white head. Big aroma of burnt sugar, ginger cake and some floral hop. Sweet maltiness in the flavour with notes of dates, oak and Marsala wine. Finish was a wonderful mix of caramel, light grassy hop, brown bread and festive spice. Big beer and very tasty.
I dont get any oakiness from the aging, nor much whiskey undertones. I prefer regular Dead Guy Ale to this. This left a weird syrupy lingering aftertaste that I didnt care for.
2/5/2010. Hazy light amber color with a white head. Aromas are fruity with caramel and malt. Oaky flavors, a little sweet with caramel and light hops.

Bottle aged a couple years. Pours orange with white head. Smells like wood and oranges, yeast. Tastes like oranges, lots of wood that comes out in the middle, creamy, medium body, smooth and easy. Good beer,

Poured into a pint glass cloudy amber brown with a light cream head with slight lacing.
Aroma of caramel sweetness & booze.
Taste is Dead Guy Ale but better. Whiskey galore. Wished it was more sweet & carbonation seems off a bit but definitely a better than average.

Purchased a case of this at the brewery and have had it in my cellar for approx 2 years. Opened the first bottle on 10/2/13. Poured amber with a nice initial head but dissipated fairly quickly. Aroma immediately has a strong essence of the Dead Guy Whiskey barrel, then the nutty maltiness of Dead Guy Ale comes through. A very nice mouthfeel with flavors of caramel, nuts, wood, and a slight (but noticeable) ethanol finish. Has a sweeter profile, much like regular Dead Guy. Ive had this on tap at the brewery and it is my opinion that the cellaring has greatly improved this beer! It is much more balanced and synchronized compared to the fresh John John which tasted like Dead Guy with a bit of whiskey mixed in. Overall, it is a definite winner in my book.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2013 Pours a hazey golden brown with an off white fizzy head the dissipates reasonably fast. Smells just lile dead guy ale with the faintest hint of barrel aged oak. The taste though is all whiskey barrel. It tastes lile a 9% carbonated Jack Daniels. Its nothing particulaterly special but its certainly worth a drink.

Rated on 10-22-2012 (Bottle) This beer pours a small tan head that had a long retention, hazy body, and spotty amounts of lacing. The Aroma is malty, spicy, whiskey and some caramel. The Taste is malty, spicy, and whiskey. The Palate is lightly tingly and this is a medium bodied beer. In conclusion, this beer is quaffable but the flavor is lacking to where it does not lend me to seek this beer out again.

Interesting beer; reminds me of a poor mans Kentucky Bourbon Barrel Ale. Good beer for the price. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer was TERRIBLE...Just TERRIBLE.
I chilled the beer to 50 degrees and poured it into a 4 ounce snifter.
The color looked good, a golden-brown ale.
Smell was OK, could smell the whiskey barrel aging a bit and thought this might be a decent drink.
Took a mouthful and holy what the heck...a combination of sour elephant dung, decaying squid heads, and pig urine in a thin watery Budweiser-like fluid. This bottle must have been a bad batch...thats all I can honestly think. It was clear though so I think it was a non-infected beer - just horrible as heck.
I paid $12 for this???
So I let it warm up and took a sip every few minutes thinking, "this is going to improve as the temp gets warmer".
No Such Luck. This remained feces in a bottle.
I felt obligated to drink it after dropping so much coin on it so I decided to mix it with a stout to make it palatable. No way, it just ruined the stout.
I dumped out the remaining 14 ounces and Im so dis-a-frickin-pointed.
Ive had a few other Rogue brews and while Im not an avid fan, they do make a few decent beers (Old Crustacean). ..but this one???OH man If I could get a refund, I would be all over that.

22 oz. from spiritus. Enjoyed this with a hunk of Beemster XO cheese. The beer is malty with heavy vanilla and oak notes. Lots of burbon in the finish. Puts a little edge on the dead guy...is it worth $12 for that kind of edge. No.

22oz served into a snifter.

No born on date, but supposedly fresh from the truck.

A - Pours a slightly hazed amber/red. 2 fingers of cream colored head looks thick and blankets the ceiling with micro-bubbles.

S - Bready malt, alcohol vapors, golden grahams cereal, faint fruit, hints of vanilla, bright fruit, peaches,

T - Bright caramel, honey sweetness, very bready, suggestions of wood, clean but doughy yeast (if that makes sense), peaches, toasted grains covered in honey.

M - Very smooth feel, light to medium bodied, semi-sweet finish.

Bright and bready are 2 words that would describe this beer.

If it wasnt printed on the label I would have never guessed this was aged on whiskey barrels.
The signature pacman yeast is very present.(nutty and doughy) The barrels seem to add creaminess and hints of vanilla. (I guess) Nice fruit profiles and nice honey flavor.

A solid beer that has grains of barrel aging and pulls it off. Outrageously overpriced so this is a one and done.

Serving type: bottle

06-08-2012
On tap at george and dragon. Orange colour with white head. Honey, caramel, malt aroma. Strong honey, sweet taste. Also caramel and malts. Light body.

Appearance:
A slightly cloudy orange under a thin splash of a white head bordered by a thin white collar. Swirls with little change.

Nose:
Malt forward followed by oak with caramel and vanillin in the back. Sauced apples sprinkled with cinnamon, nutmeg, and ginger.

Palate:
Thin mouthfeel and presentation of flavors overall with a fast finish. Sauced apples with mingle with caramel. Cinnamon-sugar and nutmeg. Raw cinnamon powder makes the top of my tongue tingle. Bitter orange rind and oak finish. Apple skins.

Final Thoughts:
Rogues Dead Guy is an original classic that helped kick-start the craft beer re-evolution along with all our other founding fathers. This barrel-aged variant was a toss-up for me; some of it I loved and some I did not. I enjoyed the additional complexity the oak added, but on the flip-side, it thinned out the palate more than I would have liked.

Maybe I was in the wrong frame of mind for this beer but it just struck me all wrong. Its not really a high ABV beer but it gives off the impression of being overly boozy and just too malty for my liking.

Pretty good drink but I am a rogue fan. Think this will be a real god summer time hot weather drink.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Gold pour with creamy white head. Aroma of sweet malt and earthy hops.  Flavor is sweet malt, pepper, and a decent flat bitter. Medium bodied but a tad foamy.
Tasted in 2010 (backlog). Gold in color with a good sized off-white head. Aroma is of wood, malt and caramel. Taste is of whiskey, light vanilla, oak and malt.

Aroma is very subtle, with whiskey notes. Dark amber colored. Very sweet with whiskey notes along with the classic dead guy flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a cloudy amber color with a huge and frothy white head. Aroma is tobacco, honey, oak, raisin, caramel, cereal, and faint licorice. Taste is raisin, honey, green wood, grass, with an almost red wine-like dry finish. Interesting, but I like the original better.

22 oz bottle served in a St. Bernardus snifter.
A: The beer is hazy orange-amber in color. It poured into my snifter with a head barely thick enough to cover the ale that quickly died down to a thin partial film over the surface and a thin ring around the edge of the glass.
S: Moderately strong aromas of malts, whiskey and wood in the somewhat fruity nose.  Interesting and complex, although not a perfect mix in my nose. 
T: The flavor is better than the aroma, with a solid malt/barley base, beer is quite malty and notes of wood and whiskey from the barrel aging process. Hints of yeast, spicy and herbal hops, honey and dark fruits are also present in the taste.
M: On the high side of medium-bodied with a very good, low-moderate amount of carbonation. Quite smooth with nearly no alcohol harshness. 

O: A rich and complex ale I enjoyed quite a bit despite having no particular fondness for whiskey. The whiskey barrel aging adds a good level of wood and whiskey to the aroma and flavor.

From notes. 22oz bottle courtesy of Erik and Eva. Poured a cloudy brown with a slight foamy head. Aromas of malts and funky yeast. Strong alcohol, nice flavours of dark fruits, figs and raisins and slight, but noticeable sour notes.

Hazy amber/orange color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of caramel malt, fruit, & hops; Flavor of sweet malt, oak, caramel, hops, and fruit; Slight alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced; Overall, a little subdued - but nice take on the original.

Tasted from the bottle @George and dragon, Barcelona,in June 2012.
Quite unusual, strange taste - almost-a-barleywine?..

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2012 Draft at Moriartys. Hazy brown pour. Not sure what I was expecting but this was not it. Getting a lot of funky sour notes. Like a flemish sour with some dark caramel malt flavors. Raisins. Whiskey oak barrel notes as well. Pungent brown sour. Only a handful of other reviews here are noting the sour element - so either this beer has turned or varies greatly keg to keg. Bizarre, but I am up for it!

It poured a dark red color with a beige head. The aroma was notes of citrusy hops, fruits and some malt. The taste was sweet with notes of malt, straw and fruit with some citrusy hops, leading to a bitter finish. Not bad.

On tap. Slightly hazy amber golden with a small, creamy off-white head. Tart aroma of overripe fruit - berries kinda. Medium body tartnsweet berry accents, a little Brett and I believe lactic acid also. Dry and tart finish. Clearly infected from the barrel but not entirely unpleasant. 261012

Drank from the bottle. Interesting character to it. Not much of a head, but a surprising amount of co2 on the tongue, given that. sweet hops and caramel malt and just a slight note of the whiskey barrels. enjoyable and above average.

Good beer! Poured at a good temperature wilth a decent size, light tan, foamy, frothy head that soon settled and some lace. Color is a clear amber with some bubble trails. Aroma is the best part here and is malt, whiskey, hop and aromatic. Flavor doesnt have mujch of the whiskey, but lots of malt and some hop comes through. Its also fairly dry with carbonic tang balanced nicely with the bitter and the slight sweet to take the edge off. Body is also excellent and is soft, but not overly and great carbonation. Finish is like flavor, good burps, a little boozy, the whiskey flavor finally comes through, and a bit on the long side.
Dark amber / ruby pour with a small beige head. Biscuit and sweet hops and whiskey. Taste same as the aroma but with less whiskey. Body lighter then the looks and aroma.

22oz bottle, shared with friends. Woody whiskey barrel aroma.  Sweet caramel malts. Smooth softer carbonation, bigger body. Clear amber color. Thin off-white head. Little lace. Light sweet taste. Little bitterness. Hint of booze. Enjoyable sipper, but not much too this, kind of one-sided.
Tasty. Definitely able to detect the whiskey, adds a nice touch. Too heavy for a daily driver.

12 ounce goblet at the Green Door, Chicago.  They offered a Rogue John John shot along with the beer, explaining that it was the same bourbon used in the beer, but I passed on the package deal. This helles bock has a fairly light mouthfeel without delving into the watery side of the spectrum. Its bright orange in appearance and has very little foam or lacing. The smell is candied fruit and the taste is more of the same. Overall this was an enjoyable twist on a beer that Id normally expect to see alongside springtime bocks, but it works well as a sweet and light fall beverage. The whiskey component is really subdued and doesnt overwhelm the other elements present.
Pours copper and smells of booze and wood. A noticeable amount of whiskey enhances the beer flavor but does not ruin it. Definitely boozy in a good way

- initially rated the wrong one , deleted that, added this!

On the deck at Rons. Thanks for the trade! Bread dough nose but not much of it. Hazy. Orange. Nice looking. Palate is heavy and rich and decent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Shared this one with JB yesterday.  Surprised we dont see his rating here yet.  Pours deep amber/ruby with a light beige head that did not stay around long. Aroma of bread and slightly toasted malts, floral hops, and a hint of whiskey in both the aroma and the flavor.  I thought this would have more body.
Bottle. Really get the taste of the barrels off this one. Alcohol flavors abound in the nose, but in a muted way, so that its very pleasant. Great brew.
On tap.  Comes dark amber with an average biege head.  Aroma of fruit, caramel, malt, and citrus.  Taste is malt, caramel, grain, dark fruit, citrus, and florals.  Interesting.  Nice.
Pours copper with little white head. Smells is grainy oak vanilla. Tastes smooth and big on oak. No complaints it is very good. Mostly earthy grain vanilla, mild warming wood.

Bomber from Woodmans in the Falls. Pours an unclear copper color with a bit of a white head. Nice lacing. Aroma has sweet hay, vanilla-y bourbon, some vegetal-ness and a hint of malt. Taste is of sweet vanilla, biscuit, caramel. Quite sweet and dry. With alcohol. Finishes dry and somewhat lingering. Like no other heller bock in the world, I am sure, and a solid drinker although nothing stands out about it beyond the vanilla/alcohol presence.
650 ml bottle. Pours a hazy orange brown with medium head  Light fruity aroma. Flavors of toasted malt and biscuits with a light oakiness. Sharp with lots of scrubbing bubbles...

Bottle: Poured a dark burgundy color ale with a rather large foamy head with good retention and minimal lacing. Aromas of whisky notes are quite dominant with some light caramel malt notes also noticeable. Taste is a good mix between the caramelized sugars from the malt backbone with some nice whisky notes that are not too boozy. Body is about average with good carbonation. Nothing earth shattering here but very nice nonetheless.
Bottle - small foamy head, medium orange/amber color, sweet malt/earthy hop aroma and flavor, can definitely taste the oak barrels - very good!

Dark orange copper ,some head.
Sweet grainy,floral fruit,carmel,slight vanilla, honey,slight tart/sour maybe just citrus.
Taste is grainy malt,sweet carmel  honey- spice,with citrus floral,pine.Kinda toasty dry woody maybe spiceyslight funk black peppery, but with body,somewhat smoothh.Some mild wisky notes.
Soupy head, kind of weak, but more than made up by a hefty malt body with strong caramel malt notes.

Hazy amber-orange color, small off-white head. Light fruity nose. Medium-bodied, rounded palate. Sweet fruity, apple flavor. Caramel, light alcohol, vanilla, low bitterness. Very interesting beer I would say.

25th July 20106.5%. Cloudy amber beer. Little white head. Light palate, softish but with a trailing carbonated bite. Smooth soft vanilla oak, with a little  coconut and just a whisper of whisky. Minerally fruits and repressed hop. Nicely joined up - good crispness for a BA beer.

Cloudy orange-amber...with a HUGE tan head.
A looong lasting head.
Scent is sweet wood, honey...vanilla.
Taste is vanilla,some alcohol,toffee, oak.
More alcohol presence as it warms.
Very good.

From notes: Poured hazy amber with a thick, off-white head.  Nice woody aroma, mixed with noted of piney hops and vanilla.  Medium-to-full body.  Woody flavor up front, giving way to bright, lemony citrus.  Some vanilla notes as it warmed.

Grifo. Vaso de ½ Pinta. Saboreada en may´12. Color naranja brillante. Capa marfileña, cremosa y persistente. Aromas florales de lúpulo, moderada malta caramelo y levadura con un toque de manzana. El malteado domina los sabores, sin embargo, quedan bien redondeados por un leve amargor. Trazos de fruta madura albaricoque y pera. Notas de malta de Whisky con ligera barrica aportan cálidez a la suave sensación en boca. Cuerpo medio y baja carbonatación. Sutil astringencia. ¿ No te gustan las Helles Bock?. Prueba ésta. Refrescante y sabrosa.
On tap. ½ Pint glass. Enjoyed on may´12. Bright orange color. Off-white, creamy, lasting crown. Floral hop, moderate caramel malt & yeasty with apple touch. Maltiness dominates flavors, eventhough they are well rounded by low bitterness. Ripe fruit -apricot & peach- hints. Whiskey malt notes in the middle, slightly wood-cask too, give a very kind warm touch to such an smooth mouthfeel. Medium body, soft carbonation. Subtle astringency. Don´t like Helles Bock style?. Try, this. Refreshing & flavorful.

Aromas of honey, peach, caramel and Im picking up some sour notes. Body is medium/full with average carbonation and a creamy mouth feel. Malt dominated with some sourness, honey and some light hops on the finish. Decent.

Deep golden copper color. Pint in Nashville TN.  Delicious hints of Bourbon and caramel in this version of the dead Guy.  My favorite is the original version  with its complex And unique flavor.  The john john twist is nice though definitely drinkable, medium bodied, mild carbonation,  just another great rogue creation.

On tap @ Humpys. Rusty amber with a thick, creamy head. Aroma is musty oak, vanilla and butterscotch. Flavor is rich bready, caramel malt with some boozy and oak character. Medium body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouth feel. This smelled pretty bad but tasted better, nice to try but wouldnt go for this again.
The draught sample came golden with a light, white head. Aromas of malt and honey. Flavors of malt, honey, and barely hoppy. Medium bodied.
Tap. Amber with dissipating head. Cant get a good smell-maybe a little peachy. Tastes like a vanilla milkshake. Even had a creamy mouth feel.
Orange amber pour, fizzy fastly dissapating head. Oaky taste tries to mask a bad blend of malts. Original dead guy is way better.

22 ounce bottle that poured a hazy orange color with aromas of vanilla, booze, fruit, caramel malts, and some wood.  Flavor is some vanilla bourbon with some hops and bitterness added to it.  Also a feint taste of some fruit on the palate.

Delicious aroma of oak and booze and vanilla.  Deep orange and copper with a big white head.  Lots of caramel flavor with a good hoppy afterbite.  Palate is quite tingly.  Its very fizzy.  Glad I tried it but probably wont repeat.  Too many other things to try!

Draft.  Pours an orangey amber with a medium-sized off-white head.  Aroma was toffee, vanilla, and some booze.  Flavor was vanilla/oak, some booze, caramel, and toffee.  Mildly sweet, very low bitterness.  Pretty tasty.

Poured a light orange/amber color with a bubbly white head that dissipated fairly quickly. The nose is of Bourbon whiskey, toasted malts and vanilla. The taste starts with a caramel sweetness then gives way to toasted malts and caramel. Oak comes next with a definite dose of Bourbon that seems to linger on the tongue throughout the beer. Doesnt remind me of the original Dead Guy at all. Medium mouthfeel. Carbonation is nice and light. Very smooth and silky. Feels far more boozy than its 6.4% suggests. As this brew warmed it became far more interesting. If youre a fan of Dead Guy you may or may not like this beer. An interesting brew to say the least.
This has a pretty malty aroma. The appearance is pretty orange with a bit of head. Mostly this tastes like a slightly stronger malty alcoholic beer. Okay but not worth anywhere near 10 bucks.
Deep orange with soft white head.  Slight funky aroma with subtle whisky and wood notes.  Light bodied, lightly malty with a funk edgemellow from the wood and whisky notes.
Draft. Pours orange with very little head. Smells of vanilla from the barrels. Not my typical choice but pretty good.

Thanks Lenore for sharing this bottle. Consumed at room temp in a Riedel Snifter

A - 1-Finger head. The beer itself was that of a light leather and there was a cloudiness to it.

S - The first smell is all honey. Theres tons of honey in this followed by citrus, peaches and kiwi. The sweetness burned the back of my throat just smelling it.

T - HONEY. Also, apples, vanilla and oak wood. 

M - There are a lot of bubbles in this beer. Its medium bodied and not much linger.

O - This beer is just too malty for my tastes. Its too sweet and too hoppy. Theres almost too much of everything.

A surprising treat from Rogue... I didnt expect the sour taste (Im assuming that comes from the whiskey barrels).
Aroma of almost a Belgian sour, almost no hop smell.
Nice feel in the mouth, with a very unique taste. Almost along the lines of a Flanders red, but holding onto the Dead Guy base.

Awesome beer.
Draught. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Spicey. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 2/1/12


Aroma: The nose is caramel malts, fruit, bourbon, vanilla, wood, and yeast

Appearance: It pours a cloudy orange color with a thick and foamy beige head and spotty lace

Flavor: The taste is mid-sweet, with vanilla, bourbon, and fruit, and it has a light bitterness on the finish

Palate: The body is light-medium, it is fairly creamy, with an average carbonation, and a long duration

Overall Impression: 
I found this one to be pretty decent, but I was surprised at how little it reminded me of Dead Guy.  It is a pretty interesting brew though, and fairly unique.  Even if the components dont all seem to work perfectly together, it still works decently overall.
Draught. Hazy Golden colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, fruit, malt and hops.

Bottle. Pours a hazy copper amber with a small off-white head that left spotty lacing. Aroma of caramel, oak, vanilla and some toffee. Flavor was semi sweet with vanilla, caramel, oak a bit of toffee and had notes of whiskey.  decent brew
Aroma of honey, wheat, and slight floral hop.  Pours red with a medium to large bubbly head.   Tastes is bizarre.  Some strong honey and floral going on here.  Weird but not unpleasant.
Bottle shared by wray043. Pours a hazy gold with a slightly sour aroma. Flavor is fruity and almost grapish! Good for what it is, but wouldnt drink it again.
Bottle from wray043 . Beer is golden with small white head. taste fruity. Slight green grape smell.

Sample @ Rogue Public House, San Francisco, CA

Pours reddish orange with a smooth white head. Aroma of caramel malts, toffee, white chocolate and hops. Taste is quite sweet and malty with notes of toffee, oak and wood. Finish is smooth and slightly fruity. Well balanced, tasty and easy to drink ale.
Draft. Didnt get any aroma at all from the beer. Also, for being aged in whiskey barrels I got very little flavor from it. It was an ok beer, but I was expecting more.

Spiciness from the whiskey barrel enhances the malt character of the base Dead Guy Ale, almost making it feel like a Scottish Ale. Aroma is clean but with lots of oak and whiskey. Decent head, but mild carbonation. Flavors of caramel, figs, and whiskey. Very little hop bitterness. Dry finish with a hint of alcohol heat. A great medium strength beer for lovers of barrel aged ales.

I rated this a while back and just now found my notes: "Clear orange amber with small head. Very fragrant; sweet and juicy. Apricot. Nectarine. Mildly bitter-sweet flavor. Fresh hops in the finish. Thin body. Good, but fades in the stretch."

650ml bottle pours amber in color with about 2 fingers of off-white head with some thin lacing.  Aroma is whiskey, caramel malts, and oak.  Taste is malty sweet with some whiskey and oak wood and some mild hops.  Medium body and smooth carbonation leave a nice feeling on the palate.  An interesting take on the original Dead Guy Ale which was quite enjoyable.

Bottle Hazy Longhorn-orange ale with a mid-sized, frothy, off-white head. Great retention. The aroma is a concoction of wood, orange pulp and sourmash  odd, but interesting. Light to medium-bodied with lively carbonation. The flavor is acidic and very watery. Virtually no malt structure. Tart and citrusy. Finishes yogurty and coarse with heaps of lactic acid. Seems both infected and over-attenuated. Bleh.

Bomber from GM Liquors. Nose is bubblegum, toffee,  and hints of  woody vanilla. Hazy copper orange with a medium, long lasting, beige head. Flavor is moderately sweet toffee, vanilla, and light whiskey notes. Not great but solid; I would buy lots if it wasnt $10 a pop!
On tap at Beer Temple. Hazy amber. Sour notes prevail, hints of vanilla. Quite acidic. Interesting.

really didnt care for this one. had it at a tasting, very vanilla with light body.  sweet whiskey taste i suppose. barrel aged flavor dominates, and i dont think it works well in this instance. not an expert when it comes to this style but i dont think its for me

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: In the nose, it kind of smells like an English barley wine, but there is a faint scent of wood and vanilla along with some aromas of honey and brittle toffee styled malts. As for the liquid, it was a glimmering straw gold color with a thin layer of creamy foam.  The flavor is semi sweet with a bitter bite in the aftertaste, but there are a considerate amount of signature Rogue hops and wood barrel. I dont know though, the whole concept of barrel aging a beer as boring as Dead Guy ale did give some added flavors and complexity, but I would think it more ideal for Rogue to BA some of their stronger ales and stouts. Who knows? Maybe those Shakespeare stouts or crustacean barley wines can really develop some transformation and make for a more interesting study of how the barrel does round out the flavor and the high alcohol content. I still enjoyed this beer a lot, and thought it to be a recipe by Rogue worth mentioning to friends.

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar, København
Pours cloudy orange/amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and cheese. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Draft at Beer Temple.  Slightly hazy amber pour with big white head.  Aroma is dominated by fudge.  Flavour is sweet fudge with vanilla and some tartness.  Interesting combination.
On tap. Pours hazy amber with a beige head. Aroma is sugary, rural, hay, corn, biscuit and caramel. Taste is also pretty sugary with caramel malts, ruraly notes here aswell, corn, hay and some hops.

22oz bottle from Picks poured into a shaker. Pours a cloudy burnt orange with a half finger of off-white head. Aroma of floral hops, wood and slight vanilla. Taste is lightly bitter. Slight taste of hops and vanilla. Very strong taste of whiskey. Medium bodied with a thin yet creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. Something I would gladly drink again in the future.

Draft. A hazy dark red beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of citrusy hops, fruits, and some malt. The flavor is sweet with notes malt, straw, and fruit with some citrusy hops, leading to a bitter finish. The body is light.
On tap. Red brown, off-white head. Sweet. Malts, fruits, grassy hops. Dry mouth feel. Peculiar aroma/taste interplay.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Hazy orange-red coloured with a small off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, dried fruits and hops with notes of oak.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits, hops and grass.
Dry hoppy finish.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2011 Draught at MikkellerBAR. Cloudy red/amber - offwhite head. Ok bitterness. Caramel. Chocolate notes. Berries. Grassy. Grainy. Bread. High sweetness. Oakey notes. Medium malty. Medium to light hoppy. A bit plain.
nose is celery, bittersweet malt, leaves, feel is watery, carb is medium, taste follows nose with sweeter malt notes, green apple and weak late hops bite

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen.
Pours a reddish brown colour with a white head. Aroma of sweet toasted malts, nuts, banana and dark berries. Flavour of sweet toasted malts, dark berries, nuts, oak and grassy hops. Medium bodied, thick mouthfeel and a finish of sweet berries and malts. Unoffensive and easy to drink.
Sampled at ABR this fall.  And, for a style Im usually not crazy about, this is an absolutely delicious beer!  I highly suggest finding some!  Dead Guy is very good, but John John DG is superb!

22oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours deep amber/ruby with a thick, light beige head.  Aroma of bread and slightly toasted malts, floral hops, and a hint of whiskey.  Nothing really sticks out in this beer.  Average texture.  A decent beer, but nothing special.
Pours reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma of honey, floral hops, and wood. Wood, whiskey, and vanilla in the flavor, somewhat thin bodied

Bomber. Pours a deep honey with orange hues. Great big vanilla oak aroma, a bit floral. Taste is sweet malt, vanilla, oak, slightest bourbon hint. A great sipper with a complex mouthy feel. Let this one warm a bit to let the bourbon breath. Very good indeed!!
An okay beer. Notes of caramel and not much else. Amber color with flavors of malt and a hint of whiskey. Nothing to see here. Move along.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Amber pour with an off white head. Aroma of wood, vanilla, toffee and lots of spices. A hint of vanilla and whiskey in the flavour. Lots of spices, caramel malts and roasted biscuit malts. One of the first beers that got us into craft brews. Loved it every way til Sunday
Pours amber with an offwhite head.  Aroma is woody, oak, vanilla and some smoke.  Taste is sweet whiskey.  Mouthfeel is oily and smooth.  I was impressed by this one.

Very slightly hazy amber with a white head that quickly recedes to a ring. It almost smells like Christmas. Maybe it sounds weird, but I smell Christmas aromas (holly, cinnamon, conife), wood, whiskey, sweet fruit. The taste is malty with a nice, sweet, woody/whiskey flavor thats far from subtle but very well integrated. I do like whiskey...

22 oz. bottle purchased at Albertsons in Mill Creek, WA.  Pours a beautiful amber color with a cream-colored head.  Aroma:  Citrus, spice, and pineapple.  Flavor:  Same as the aroma, with a hint of whiskey (obviously).

Pour was light amber, frothy head.  Okay, its a barrel aged Dead Guy.  I couldnt taste a whole lot of Dead Guy under it all.  A lot of wood flavor and a hoppy tart zing, which seemed oddly out of place.  The whiskey was there, but not overpowering.  Just ok.

Bottle; Pour is murky golden with a fine bubbled, off white head that does seem to retain well. The nose is caramel, vanilla, and oak, as the notes state. The Dead Guy Base practically disappears here.  The Vanilla/Oak notes are heavy here; it feels a bit unbalanced; perhaps its not the best base beer to barrel age. Anyway - its not bad... but.

22oz bottle.
Orangish amber pour with a sticky white head.  Aroma is whiskey, bready malt, floral hops, and oak.  More bready malt in the flavor with some wood and vanilla.

Bottle.  A golden color with a white head.  The malty aroma is cut with the whiskey.  Interestingly, the balance between the two mutes both.  The whiskey comes through in the flavors in this well balanced beer for its style.
UPDATED: JUL 29, 2011 22 oz bottle pours a amber/orange color with a nice white head.  Aromas of malt, wheat, and whiskey.  Light bodied with a nice whiskey finish/

Sampled on tap at PIB. Pours cloudy orange/brown with a fine white lacing. Aroma of perfume, yeast, molasses, and tropical fruits. Flavour of perfume, tropical fruits, banana and lightly burnt caramel. Dry, fruity and sweet, but too similar to drinking perfume.

In short: A slightly woody semi-sweet golden lager.  Just ok
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed a few months after purchase.  
The look: Cloudy golden amber body topped by a small off-white head
In long: Nose is a tiny bit spicy, some flowers and some old dirty moist barn wood.  Body is a bit fluffy, pleasant soft caramel and honey, strangely some coconut notes, some wood.  Low hops presence.  The barrel aging is certainly not overwhelming in this beer, Ive had beers that were not barrel aged and that had woody undertones that were as strong as in this one.  Taste is also a bit buttery but not DMS or anything, it just felt naturally buttery.  I dont know why I bought that beer.  But me doing things with no reason is not surprising considering that Im a card-carrying member of the Useless Membership Club.

Sampled on tap at PIB, pours hazy orangey amber with a small head. Aroma of perfume, yeast and subtle dark fruits. FLavour of light whiskey barrels, caramel malts, toasted nuts and a light head. Very solid but not as good as regular Dead Guy.

Bottle at le mondiale 2011. 
This was an interesting beer. The aroma right off the bat was bready, cereal, caramel, malts. But the barrel ageing added a thick buttery aro a and flavor to the beer. It reminded me alot of innis and gunn beers, and their butter barel aged disasters they call beer. Anything after that first sip was oak, vanila, thick malts with a healthy dose of butter. Some beer styles just shouldnt be barrel aged if you ask me.

650ml brown bottle. Pours out deep gold to orange, slightly unclear. Retains a nice thin bead of slightly off white bubbles. Great malty aroma, notes of caramel. Flavour also strongly malty, starts out with caramel sweetness, some nutty and toasty malt hints, oranges, whisky comes in late addiing some woody notes.  Slight bitter finish with lingering whisky notes. Medium body, lots of fine carbonation, overall nice mouthfeel. Good use of whisky barrels with this beer.

Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  Coppery with a decent tan head.  A funky and musty aroma that reminds me of a furniture warehouse.  Quite different and not unpleasant.  Some cool flavors.  Pine sap, wood, vanilla.  The flavor is also musty.  I didnt taste the whiskey but it definitely added interesting qualities.

22oz bomber split with Ann.  Won on eBay for $2.24..local pickup!  Murky amber-tan color.  Steady, creamy head.  Clean and fresh, smooth malt tones with some mild hop roughness.  Not really a HellerBock in any respect at this point, this is still a pretty nice beer.  Exceptional balance.  Doughy vanilla tones are complemented by the oaky bourbon.  Great beer, expertly executed.
Cloudy copper color with an aroma of vanilla, toffee, and some hops.  Lots of caramel and vanilla flavor with toffee, and a touch of oak.  No noticeable whiskey flavor.  Still a nice beer.
Whats not to like? Dead Guy in whiskey barrels? First off, Dead Guy is great in its own right. Age it in whiskey and it gets a bit more complex with some oak and vanilla. I gotta get the hazelnut.
On tap at Mahars. Pours a nice dark with a really thick head. Aroma is flat and earthy. Flavor is hops and barley, roasted sweet and grassy.
On tap at Zenos. Interesting beer. Pours hazy amber with quarter inch cream white head. Aroma is faint caramel. Flavor is sweet--caramel/honey, a little citrus and faint oak.

Bomber from Martin City Brewing Co. in south KC.  Pours honey/copper with a bright white head that leaves nice lacing.  Very faint oak aroma, which is equally subtle in taste.  Almost no trace of whiskey or spirits, just a slightly amped up Dead Guy....and theres nothing wrong with that!  Light bready malt, a touch of floral hops, and a clean finish.

Pours a golden orange color with a huge frothy white head that sticks around for a bit. Smells of sweet malt with a some bread, vanilla, and some toffee. I pick up some faint oak but its really hidden. Taste is sweet with honey, toffee and caramel up front. I get the whiskey, vanilla, and oak next. Then a stinging higher alcohol thats almost vodka like and hop bitterness in the finish. Thick sticky mouthfeel, medium level of carbonation, medium body. I tried to enjoy this one, but its not for me. I dont think the flavors meld very well and the alcohol burn kills it for me.

poured nice copper orange color with a decent head that fleeted quickly to give a nice white line all the way to the end of the beer.  nose was a little sour with a hint of oakey ending. tasted a little tart to start that faded into a nice sweetness and finished with a  nice oakey aftertaste.

Dark gold with decent, creamy, white head / Elegant nose of wood, cream, and citrus / Medium body, creamy with a hint of sweetness, stylish balance between good malts and hops, alcohol well masked, with long, lightly bitter, finish / Flavors of oak, whiskey, orange, pineapple, and coconut / A great concoction.
Draught.  Pours copper with a tan head.  Smells of dark fruit, some malty hints, lightly spicy.  Tastes rosey with some caramel and spicy hints on the finish.

Bottle @ home. Copper orange appearance with a two finger cream colored head. Somewhat spicy, vanilla, oak, light whiskey, sweet pale malty nose. Big, sweet pale malty bock flavor with a big sweet, vanilla, light woody taste. Quite sweet finish with a hint of booze but overall the beer is very smooth. Good one.

Tap @ Cheeky Monk, Denver doing the oyster event. Pours goldel with a big white head. Aroma of honey, vanilla, oak and bourbon. Taste is oak, bourbon, honey, caramel, pine needles. Medium body, low carbonation. 130411

Bomber.   I remember the original, and I thought why change it!!!????  It was a great beer.  But, I have to admit, I enjoyed this beer very much, Fruity aroma, thin white head,   Light brownish in color with a malt aroma.  Nice balance, can taste the caramel, vanilla and oak (almost bourbon like) finish.

Pours a hazy honey color with a long-lasting foamy white head. Malt, caramel, alcohol, oak, vanilla, a slight spicy hop character in the nose. Quite light in body, slick on the tongue with a long astringent finish. Lightly sweet upfront, but a dry boozy finish. Easy to drink, good character, the whiskey barrel and the dead guy ale complement each other well.

Bottle. Orange and slightly cloudy. Plenty of body for its relatively medium strength. Orange peel like flavour with explosions of citrus and cinammon.
Definitely a one off and really worth trying.

Bottle. Dark amber with a lasting light froth. Aroma of a Dead Guy is malty with some sweetness and a hint of spirits. Flavour is definately changed with the whiskey barrel treatment. Strong Whisky touch that seems to smooth out the beer. As described caramel, vanilla, oak and alcohol. Pairs well with dry cake or cookies.

Big bottle, big price, OK beer.  Aroma caramel, vanilla, slight alcohol.  Taste mild with sweet malts, caramel, toffee, vanilla and hops.  Mild to moderate hop finish.  Palate smooth with moderate carbonation.  I did not get much whiskey flavor.  This is a nice beer, but not  what I expected.

Bottle. Pours lightly hazy orange, thin off-white head, weak lacing. Nose is spicy hops, nice rich malt, strong whiskey notes, some cream and vanilla. Flavours of dry, almost sour whiskey, some vanilla, spicy hops, strongly malty, sweet finish. Good.

Tap at Falling Rock.  Pours clear copper with a medium, fizzy white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is average malt (bread, cookie, caramel, biscuit), heavy hops (floral, pine, citrus), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of oak and alcohol.  Flavor is average malt (bread, cookie, caramel, biscuit), heavy hops (floral, pine, citrus), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of oak and alcohol.  Medium body, warmth, and carbonation with a dry finish.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. Hazy medium orange body, thin beige head. Light nose at cold serving temperature, revealing dominant notes of oak and vanilla as it warms. The body is harsh, too light to balance the strong tannic, buttery oak, vanilla, and alcohol. Caramel notes are delicate and overwhelmed. Not every beer smiles at the barrel.

Bomber from Whole Foods Tampa.  Pours a hazy orange-gold with an off-white head.  Nose is vanilla, oak, caramel, a hint of malts, and some wood/ barrel.  Flavor is malt, vanilla, whiskey, honey, and some yeast.  Medium bodied and nice enhancement of regular DG with the really clean whiskey flavor.  I can taste regular Dead Guy in this through the barrel flavor and can see where the whiskey is adding to this one.  The somewhat abrasive finish of Dead Guy is made softer by the gentle barrel and whiskey of this one.  Enjoyable.

Pours Brown with a thin white head low retention. Aroma is very malty It It really smells like Dead Guy. But there are notes of fruit coming through as well no doubt from the barrel. Flavour is very nice. It has the light malty drinkability of Dead Guy with a very subtle whiskey notes. oak and vanilla come through and leave a slightly fruity after taste. This is a very nice beer it is well balanced and I appreciate that the flavours from the barrel do not over power the base. Dead Guy is one of my favorite beers and I have really enjoyed this fresh expression of the brew. Very nice.

Bottle from EZ. Thanks Ant. Pours out a well carbonated amber color with a small white head. Aroma is of lots of caramel, and some earth. Taste is sweet caramel, whiskey, some buttery toffee, oak, light vanilla, and some honey. Very sweet and definitely not worth the price tag on this one.

Altamonte Springs, Fl - ABC Liquors - 22 oz bomber. Pours a murky dark orange with little to no head. Aroma is sweet and reminds of honeysuckle, oranges and a hint of bourbon. Flavor is on the sweet side with some honey notes, some sweet whiskey (think Southern Comfort), some molasses and a touch of raisins. Mouthfeel is decently thick. A little too sweet for my liking - not to the point of cloying - but 12 oz would have been enough.
Sample from bottle.  Orange amber pour, off-white head.  Mostly comprised of sweet malts (caramel, toffee, and bread), a bit of fruit, oak, and touch of vanilla.  Certainly worth trying once.

Poured out a thick bright white cap that takes its time to settle down, murky amberish brew. The aroma is very butterscotch based, quite similar to an Innis & Gunn (boo). My hand smells like tacos. Now I have to review lefty.. blind date beering! lots of caramel, a bit of vanilla, oak.. hey! I just copied the description! Where is the Dead Guy here? The taste is damn fine with its oaky, vanillay, butterscotchy, yy, light spice, interesting fruit of some sort (feeling lazy), no bitterness until the faintest sign at the end of the odd sip an d now that I picked that up I can find that much easier. Damn this is tasty. Excellent excellent mouth feel - ultra smooth, light coating, light lingering spice... this is soothing and awesome in my mouth. The beer smells decent, tastes better and feels amazing. Not often I say that. I want another one just to feel happy. Extra bonus points for the happiness.
Draught.  Like a dead guy but more delicate and a bit of a butterscotch twist. Good.

Bomber. Poured into Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE:

Pours deep golden orange with amber hues. Hazy. Large 2 finger head is somewhat pillowy, off-white Baileys Irish cream colored, and has medium retention duration. 


AROMA: Malty, some earthy/spicy hops, subtle wood aroma, some vanilla-like characteristics from the wood (though more like vanilla extract than vanilla bean), and faint spice. Good amount of wet cereal grain. Wood aroma is somewhat off  like some old cheap wood; hardly as pleasant as some other oak aromas that I have experienced. Unable to discern much whiskey notes on nose. Some light char aroma, which was somewhat pleasant. As it warms up, aroma exhibits much more old wood (unpleasant) as well as faint whiskey notes (pleasant). 


TASTE: Malt, cereal, and some hops dominate. 

Light vanilla as well as some faint taste of old wood on mid palate. 

Back of palate has subtle whiskey note. 

Faint copper/metallic taste on finish. 

Some bitterness on finish. Hops on finish as well as back of palate seem somewhat spicy with light earthy notes. Finish also has a faint spice character that seems like a combination of spice tastes from the hops as well as the barrel. 

MOUTH FEEL: On the lighter side of medium bodied. Crisp, nice carbonation. Semi-dry. Extremely faint alcohol warmth  likely it is this discernable at this abv because the body is quite thin. 


OVERALL: Expected more whiskey notes on aroma and taste. Plenty of cereal taste. Overall, like slightly bitter cereal. Unable to say am biggest fan of the style, though found it ok. At the least, the complexities from light barrel aging can be appreciated. Wanted to like it more than I did. Brilliant concept; less than spectacular execution. Perhaps if both the whiskey as well as the beer (at their separate stages) were aged in the barrel longer, this would be a more interesting beer. According to Rogue: the whiskey only sits in the barrel 30 days, and the beer only sits in the used whiskey barrel 2+ months  each stage could have been longer.

The aroma is not as bourbonish as I had anticipated but it does have some to go along with the butterscotch, caramel, and wood. The appearance is hazy amber with a small head. The taste is like the aroma but very easy to drink. The palate is a bit thin. Overall a beer I like.
I am getting a weak flavor both in aroma and taste. taste is slightly tart. getiing a grainy consistany. not quite what I was expecting.
The bourbon didnt really save it, still is a moderately forgettable frankenbier.

Hmm. This was good, but I hoped for more. Nice brown pour with a whiskey wood aroma. Caramel mallt, vanilla and spice complement the wood whiskey taste.

It was good.
Draft at RnH with Linh. Pours a golden amber, red with slight lacing. Aroma is light fruit and malts. Flavor is mild fruit notes and sweet malt?

Pours thin with a caramel color.  Light head.  Very light and airy nose.  Taste is malt which is quickly dominated by bourbon.  Very strong, but not unpleasant bourbon flavor.  Surprisingly clean finish.

Pours a cloudy dark golden orange color with burnt orange hues when held to a light and a 1.5 finger yellowish off-white head. Pretty good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves streaks ans spots of lacing behind.

The aroma of this beer is dominated by the barrel character with hints of earthy oak, sweet boozy whiskey, vanilla, marshmallow and toasted coconut. Underneath there is some pale malt character with hints of toffee, biscuit and hazelnut but the nose is all about the barrel.

Medium bodied with a very prominent whiskey barrel flavor that overpowers most of the other characteristics and lingers into a slightly hot, dry finish. Lots of whiskey flavor without being overly hot with hints of toasted, earthy oak, vanilla and toasted coconut. The base beer is overpowered but underneath there are still hints of pale malt, caramel, toffee and biscuit. Its still pretty good, and at the relatively low ABV, pretty easy to drink but it could stand to be more balanced and have a little less one-dimensional whiskey barrel flavor.

Bottle, shared with Parksy. Light hazy amber, brief whispy head. Aroma is very odd-- the expected oaky sweet barrel character is inescapable, but underlying this is a mealy dogfood-ish smell that is not very appealing to me. Palate is sweet and boozy, with tons of vanilla oaky wood. This solves a bit of an ongoing question for me: does barrel aging actually work with a pale malted beer base? Innis &Gunn have built a business around this idea, but my main criticism of their brews has been the lack of malt structure and quantity in their beers, so Im never sure whether the concept fails, or just I&Gs execution of the concept. Well, I know for a fact that the base beer here is outstanding, and since it clearly takes nothing positive away from barrel aging, it leaves me to say that barrel aging is best left to toasted and roasted malt brews, as the pale malt character here has been drowned in the barrel.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle.  Copper golden color with a short lived foamy white head.  Nose is vanilla and oak.  Very creamy flavor.  Tastes like vanilla cream soda with oak and a mild hop backdrop.  A little alcohol heat lingers on the roof of my mouth.  My friend remarked that this is a good beer for fringe drinkers aboard new to craft brew.

22oz Bottle. Thanks for sharing, Jeff. Going in, I was suprised to see the choice of Dead Guy for barrel aging. I didnt think a pale, above-average hoppy Maibock could really hold up to a barrel. And it didnt. There wasnt anything wrong with execution of this beer, just the concept. Nose brings big oak and raw whiskey. Flavors are similar with added sweetness and no sign of the base beer. Youd be hard pressed to pick a family beneath what is essentially beer-rinsed barrel dregs. I refuse to give this points for being a good Heller Bock because its barrel aged. In fact, I think its a terrible example of a Heller Bock as result of being barrel aged.

(bomber, 5/17/10). Clear amber color. Large off white head. Light grassy/citrus hop aroma. Moderate hop flavor, with light malt and light oak. Avg duration. Light bitter finish with light dryness. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
Does not taste like an amplified or aged Dead Guy Ale, much more different, not bad, just not as good as the regular.

Bottle thanks to my friend Skinny Heitz. Pours copper with a thick caramel colored head and solid lacing. Taste is big brown sugar, caramel, slight bits of oak and whiskey. Aroma is similar, but with more of the oak and whiskey. Rather thin in the mouth, and something slightly off-putting that I couldnt quite put my finger on. Ive had worse beers though.
Had this on draft. Pours clear amber gold with a frothy white head. Aroma of mild caramel and mild hop. Taste is also milder than I expected, mostly caramel sweetness. Solid, I was just wanting more.

Tasted on 12/29/10 from a 22oz bomber bottle purchased at Discount Liquor.  Pours a cloudy orange with a thin white head that leaves only very thin and spotty white lace.  The nose is primarily the sweet aroma of whiskey with a good amount of caramel, some hops bitterness, and graham cracker.  The flavor is whiskey and oak all the way through, with some malt up front, light citrus on the middle, and burnt brown sugar and bitterness on the back.  The body is medium with lively and stinging carbonation, and a long burnt brown sugar and roasted bitterness finish.

Bottled.  A reddy amber coloured beer with slight haze and a big white head.  A big fruity hoppy note to this.  Berries and bread throughout.  US hoppy profile rather than German. Aroma:humle malt brød rugbrød citron tømmer røg Ud.:rødgylden uklar  Skum:fløde luftig mellenh. E.smag:sød moderat bitter moderat  Krop:medium til fuld  For.:cremet  Brus:livlig

On tap at Anodyne. Surprisingly quite good. Enhanced the strengths of dead guy and minimized the weaknesses. It was sweet, but the barrel aging made it like a brandy or liqueur. Not terribly complex, but kinda interesting and everything worked well together.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2011 @Tampa Wkly Gathering @TampaPourhouse Thanks Ibrew2or3-22oz bottle-pours a white head with amber dolor.  Aroma is grain/wood, peach.  Taste is grain/wood, peach/apricot pits, some vanilla, spice hops.

22oz bottle.  Pours a golden orange with a fluffy two fingers head that fell slowly to a ring.  Aroma of vanilla, oak, toffee, biscuits and a hint of whiskey.  The taste is full flavored with roasted malt,brown sugar,bread yeast, and caramel with the whiskey flavors peaking through in the finish.  Dry and smooth. Lighter bodied with medium carbonation.

22 oz bottle. Pour with a pretty big foam at first that goes away pretty fast. Hazy orange gold in color. Nose is sweet. Candy, toffee, butter, vanilla, lots of oak. Taste is more of the same. Buttered toast, baked buttered rolls. A bit of sweet whiskey and butterscotch. Hard candy. Malt. Pretty good for this style. But very one dimensional.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear medium amber color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, brown sugar, light moderate hoppy, dark orange - citrus. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, malty, hoppy, bourbon - whisky notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101022]

650ml bottle.
Hazy honey gold body. Persistent thick white head.
Buttery vanilla oak on the nose obvious from the word go. Bit of honey and cereal malt in the background. Not a great deal of hop detectable.
Creamy texture, very full, length body with moderate carbonation.
Oak flavours dominate palae; butter, toast, vanilla, butterscotch. Minimal touch of cereal malt and floral hop. Smooth finish, not much bitterness.
Tasty beverage. Enjoyable beer, reminds me of the experimental oak beers ive brewed in my time.

A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a four finger thick, tan colored head that leaves lots of nicely layered lacing on the sides of my glass.  The beer is an amber color that shows a hazed, gold-amber hue when held up to the light.  As I pour this it smells salty and perhaps smoky like a whiskey can be.  A focused smell of this beer shows ample coconut notes and vanillin, it is hard to get much of anything else.  Since this beer is only ~6.5% it doesnt have the heat that many a barrel aged beer does, and this is rather nice.  Some buttery oak notes and perhaps a hint of nutty, caramelized malt round things out.  I could honestly be imagining the malt influence as the barrel is so clearly dominant in the nose; luckily it is nice and smooth, such that this is enjoyable to smell.

My first sip is lightly sweet up front with a caramelized malt character, while the finish has some tart whiskey notes as well as some light coconut and oak-spice woodiness.  The spiciness in the finish seems to take on the role of balancing sharpness that a hop bitterness usually plays.  The middle of this beer has a nice buttery oak note that is wrapped up in the toasted coconut flavors, but the butter character is more dominant in the flavor than the coconut.  This has enough body to stand up to the barrel and actually has quite a bit of viscous body given the beer strength.

An interesting beer, perhaps a bit simplistic, but I am actually enjoying this more than I thought I would.  The base beer is definitely thoroughly dominated by the barrel character, but I like that such a light beer is able to not let this get too out of control.  You definitely will have to enjoy Whiskey-barrel aged beers to like this and I like that this is not hot and that the Whiskey character is so smooth.
orangish color some white foam, nose is oak and caremel malt, sweet flavor a bit grainey with some nice woody notes

Bottle. Pours deep orange with small white head. Aroma: coconut, pine, spruce, vanilla and sweet malt. Palate is dominated by huge amounts of American oak. I found this too be a little too much, almost sickly sweet. I dont like american oak though, so Im a bit biased.

As neither a big fan of Barrel Aged Beers or Rogue Dead Guy I was surprized... I really enjoyed this beer. Lovely spicy, caramel and earthy red malty notes blended very well with the vanillin and wood notes from the oak - also got some smoked bacon and chilli notes.

Bottle. Pours an orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Sweetish malty grainy caramel flavor with some weak woody hints. Has a sweetish malty caramel finish with some woody hints in the aftertaste.

beer is orange, thin head, with some lacing. fruit smell is upfront with grapefruit and bitter orange, some hazelnut in the background. taste is strong strong and sweet with more red grapefruit, some honey, toast, ends for a long time with dry cedar and scotch. Medium body, a little flat. Fun to sip and enjoy like a scotch.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle at BeerDig 2011 on 03/06/2011. Slightly hazy light amber body with a small off white head. Sweet fruit and toasty malt aroma. Sweet toasty bready flavor with light vanilla. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 7/3/7/4/15 3.6

On 9/16/2010. Cloudy orange body with a small off-white head. Sweet floral and resiny hop aroma. Big citrus and caramel flavor. Medium full body with moderate carbonation. 7/3/6/3/13 - 3.2

Pours a golden-orange color with a thick creamy head. I didnt sense much of a Maibock in the aroma, with the barrel imparting a definite woodsy character that was about the only aroma I could definitively identify.  The flavor is no different, with a soft, woodsy, peaty flavor like a Scotch rather than a bourbon sweetness. The whiskey is certainly not overpowering, though, with the flavors being quite soft, and I wouldnt call this one boozy. There is a bit of lingering earthy hop bitterness, and the mouthfeel is more like the beer I expected, with a resinous, almost buttery texture that is substantial but not too heavy.
The oak, malt and sweet flavors meld together for an exceptionally smooth and silky experience.  Just enough bitterness to keep it from falling too far on the sweet side.

Large creamy head good strong carbonation clear red brown pour aromas vanilla whiskey caramel good mix of malts flavour a malt whiskey like start toffee caramel vanilla smoothness a bitter of medium ibu there is a sweetness in the malts that hits the tongue whiskey gives it a smokeyness as well finish smooth sweet lightly smokey decent lasting bitter

Draft at brewvival.  Pours a semi-clear amber with ring of white head. Herbal, slightly vegetal nose.  Flavors of whisky on the tail end with a floral hop flavor bite.  Not bad, but didnt really care for this one. Better in theory than in practice I suppose.  The juniper gin was much better.
So good! Full of really nice flavor from the Whiskey Barrels. Really pushes this to a new level.

Was quite pleasantly surprised to find this on a recent excursion to Lawrence. Pours a rather vibrant ruby red to rust ornage with a high level of carbonation and a large billowing head thats a full inch high. The nose is very fruity and floral; though there is some woody notes likely due to the barrel aging. The hops accentuate the floral notes, this beer makes my mouth water. Light mouthfeel from such a complex beer, I was expecting it to be somewhat syrupy but its not nearly that heavy. Kind of disappointing, actually. The first thing you notice about the beer is the finish. Up front it has all the qualities of a nice pale ale. Theres some fruity hop things going on giving way to malt sweetness. But the finish to this beer is almost mind blowing. Theres this terrific flowered wood finish that reminds me of a creek in spring, or something similar. I dont really care for the minor alcohol notes, most likely from the aging process, but thats to be expected given this style of beer. As the beer opens up it gives you a lot more from the flavor profile. The hops are floral. I get lavendar, marigold, maybe even lillies. Quite lovely. These accent the sweet caramel malt, finally leading into that wonderful finish. Its a very circular flavor, if that makes sense. Theres not a lot of breadiness or biscuit qualities to this beer, its very light on the palate and quite delacte. This wasnt what I was expecting from this beer at all, but its enjoyable and delicious, a perfect compliment to the end of another day in a neverending hot summer.

Absolutely crystal clear copper color with a thin white head.   The whiskey/wood aroma is evident from the first whiff.  Smooth, creamy, sweet and drenched in whiskey goodness, yet very well balanced with a light hop bitterness in the background.  Light vanilla and butterscotch lay down on the tongue and stay there.   Really delicious and well made beer!
This got better as I got into it, at first the oak and whisky notes were a bit too dominant, then noticeable bock characters. Good drink but I am not always fussed about oak aging.

Oh my is this smooth. Pours from the bottle to a gorgeous white head that complements the reddish color. The vanilla scent of the malts comes through to create a lightly sweet taste. It is a full-bodied ale that has a long, satisfying finish. The Johns have created a beauty. I know what Ill be giving my nephew (a Dead Guy fan) for Christmas.
22 oz Bottle -- Pours amber with a small off-white head.  Aromas of peach, vanilla, caramel, and yeast.  Some definite bourbon flavors.  Very smooth with medium to lively carbonation.

bottle thanks to Danny at the Tally tasting, pours brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is thin barrel and toasted malts, some brown sugar.  Flavor is a malt bomb, rich and doughy with a mild booze in the finish.
Bottle. Poured copper with a creamy off-white head that settled to a ring and left light lace. Aroma of whiskey and musty oak. The flavor found vanilla, malt, and spices. Medium body.

Bomber:  Pours a cloudy copper/orange with a fluffy off-white head, vanilla, caramel, and light alcohol in the aroma, medium bodied, slick mouthfeel, subdued carbonation, starts lightly bitter ends lightly sweet with a pear ending.

Bomber. Clear copper with a lasting ring of foam. Nose is caramel, vanilla, oak. Flavors are the same but more pronounced, with the barrel making a nice showing. Finish has lightly peppery oak and light char with a counter-punch of vanilla. Near-medium body is just a tad too fizzy. Pretty nice job of balancing a big barrel against a delicate beer.

22 ounce bottle.  Served in a pilsener glass, the beer pours a cloudy amber/orange color with about a half inch off-white head.   Head retention and lacing are both decent.  Aroma is nice and malty, it smells like oak, whiskey, vanilla, caramel and a bit of spice.  It tastes like whiskey, oak, caramel malt, vanilla, and a bit of apple and spice.  The whiskey/oak flavors arent overpowering at all, I thought it would be somewhat stronger in the taste since the whiskey/oak aromas were stronger.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a little bit oily and creamy, and also has moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is OK, its certainly not hard to drink.  Not a bad brew overall, I think its worth trying.
Nice orange color. Nose is clean a bit of malt and spice. Bitter earthy taste. Yumm

Bottle.Pours a thick, lush honey orange with an aroma of fresh oak, malted whiskey, and mountain cabin air.  A slight tinge of musty bread also appears.  Flavor is whiskey malt cereal in a base of peach and bread, with hints of cheddar cheese and pancake syrup in the finish.  Nice mouthfeel, but needs more slickness.  Overall, not a bad beer but it could be much better.  Seems to be content to appeal to a wide audience rather than an audience that appreciates the intricacies of a brew aged in whiskey barrels.  Plus Im glad its not another alias.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: 22oz bomber. Aroma is very woody (fibrous, oaky) and perfumy with soft, fruity malts. Pours cloudy orange brown with a medium thick pocked light tan head. Flavor starts malty with surprisingly grassy and herbal wood tones. Bready caramel malts with hints of booziness towards mid-palate. Alcohol and whiskey grow towards the finish but still somewhat subdued. Dry, cakey, woody finish. Mouthfeel is full-bodied with slightly ethereal carbonation and a texture that turns creamy. Overall, not bad - but woodiness overpowers the Dead Guy a little.
Pours a hazy amber into a shaker. Bright white micro head recedes to skim surface. Caramel malt and whiskey aromas. Soft with front to back sweet tea and oak with a lasting hot finihs.

Ulysses ($6.50): Pours a brownish, hazy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is of scotch, wood, and spices. At first tasting, when it was still cold, the whiskey just dominated too much and indeed made it hard to drink, but after warming up, the creamy texture of the beer and the malty notes became more manifest and allowed for enjoyment of a higher quality. Interesting beer, that seems to almost be more whiskey than beer.

Bomber pours deep gold with slight haze and modestly creamy off white head. The aroma has moderate spicy hops then quickly moving into sweet vanilla, coconut and modest whiskey tones. The taste is pretty smooth and allowing spicy hops, various citrus like hops and sweet malts to shine briefly before the flavor picks up firm barrel notes of oak covered with vanilla then coconut and then a thin layer of whiskey. This was way more balanced between beer notes and barrel notes than I was expecting making it a real treat (I love to taste beer when Im drinking beer).
Clear orange color with a small head. Aroma is quite bland. Some oak and light thin whiskey. Flavor has some whiskey but the beer is gone. Some oak, very watery.

Rogue Ales--Oregon Brewing Company--John John Ale--Dead Guy Ale Aged in Dead Guy Whiskey Barrels--2010 22 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  40 IBUs.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Maibock  Ale--Whiskey.  Rich lacy dense foamy off white head.  Clear bright light amber orange color.  Bottle Conditioned, but no sediment.  Hazes at end.  Mild vanilla hop whiskey aroma.  Mellow sweet fruit ester oak hint mild caramel Maibock Ale body.  Smooth mild whiskey balanced hop spice end.  Easy whiskey barrel aged brew.  Sampled 7/9/2010.  2 @ $9.99 Each.

bottle from papago drank on 2/20/10.

dark orange iced tea color with a trim white head. 

very malty and caramel-y aroma followed with spicy bourbon notes, brown sugar, prickly green wood and orange.

the flavor is the same but surprisingly boozy and hoppy. it is fairly dry throughout with a light bitterness on the finish and a spicy, smoky wood aftertaste which lingers. it doesnt put up much of a fight as it goes down... maybe they should have thrown a better beer in the barrels (although it is far better than the original).
 crisp, clean, dry and easy to put away. 7/4/7/3/14/3.5

Faint aroma of whiskey and oak...  Flavor of scotch whiskey isnt overwhelming, much better and less overpowering than most scotch ales that Ive had...   Sweet notes of caramel noticeable which balance out the flavor from the oak... Very nicely done.

Amber with a fairly thick and frothy head.  Aroma is of tons and tons of malt - powerful.  Taste is slightly sweet - like a bit of brown sugar.  The finish has a bit of taste of oak, but it seems that theres tannins in there too.  As the finish lingers, flavors of dark, dried fruits come out.  My only objection is the hit of tannin partway through the finish.

22 ounce bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a hazy amber color with a thin head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma of whisky, wood, sawdust, caramel. The taste is caramel, whisky, wood and a fruity/hoppy finish. Medium bodied and quite tasty. 6/4/10
6/26/10.  Shared by me at the Tally Tasting 2010.  Malty, a bit of metal, wanna try the spirit itself.  Not bad!

Bottled.  poured a copper, orange color with a two finger white head.  aroma: big boozy bourbon and caramel.  taste: nice hoppy bitterness in the beginning then earthy taste from the oak,  boozy taste from the bourbon, nice sweetness from the bourbon. caramel hints, nice clean finish.

Rye whiskey nose, with juniper accents. Clear dark amber, thick head, some retention. Whiskey flavor, but still quite malty and beery. Oak finish. Alcohol subdued but present. Very approachable for those who arent fans of whiskey, like me. Well crafted and executed.

Odd.  My experience with this beer differs significantly from many of the other raters.  Pale clear copper, slight head.  Aroma is honey sweetness, a touch of oak, and a floral note.  Flavor starts off with a combination of honey malt sweetness, moves into a light oak and whiskey flavor, and then finishes with a strong floral hoppiness - not bitter, but clearly floral hop in nature.  Maybe even a touch medicinal when combined with the whiskey.  Not my favorite unfortunately, but then again, Ive never been a big fan of Dead Guy, so I cant say Im surprised.

Wow... would you look at the color of that beer!  Glowing orange - very honey-like, and a little foggy, with a billowy white head and spotty, thick lacing.  Aroma wreaks of oak.  Flavor is also dominated by oak and... I cant tell... maybe a little vanilla.  Otherwise, what malt and caramel is really hard to pull out.  This is almost over the top, and I wouldnt suggest this to someone not down with oak pummeling.  Good, but I think too much oak for the style.  I made an oaked ESB that I was almost ashamed of because I though I over-oaked it, and it tastes better than this.  By the way, this goes great with asparagus.

bomber - Pours hazy orange with a one finger head.  It smells of oak, malt, and ample whiskey.  The flavor is sweet with obvious whiskey that goes really well with the bock.  Its the strongest flavor but doesnt overpower the beer.  Hints of honey and vanilla complete this tasty, medium bodied brew.
Cloudy orange color with white head. Can smell the whiskey wood immediately.   Wonderful subtle whiskey woody esters with some coriander and vanilla.

Tap at Pacific Standard.  Deep orange pour.  The nose is a little bit orangey with a distinct, but fairly subtle vanilla note.  A little bit sweet and syrupy with a kiss of toffee and some light sugar.  Fairly sweet.  Its soft and pretty easy to drink but it doesnt really have any sort of punchiness at all.  A little bit of vanila but I dont get much oakiness at all.

Pours out a lovely deep gold, classic Rogue dense head.  Aromas are really appealing, fruit, vanilla, some marzipan & for me a waft more reminisent of rum perhaps with all that vanilla some burnt mollasses/caramel.  Body is rich & creamy, lots of malt & fruitiness with vanilla & those background notes from the whisky, sweet barley & caramel.  I really enjoyed this but its quite a rich brew so one to share from the 22oz bottle.

22oz bottle.  Orange amber color.  Tall creamy tan head.  Aroma of peat moss, barley, cooked barley, oak, vanilla,  and wood.  

Flavor is soft malt,  Lots of barley, light distant hops.  Very mellowed out by the wood.  The lightest flavors of salt and whiskey.  Finishes with a touch of wood flavor. 
Smooth on the palate, perhaps the creamiest texture Ive exer had in a beer.  Amazing.  So soft.  Perfection (except for the price).

Bottle: Clear gold with very little to no head. The nose is fruity with some light pale malt and woody notes, but really theres not a lot going on. Big mouthfeel but the body isnt there, the malts are all thin and sweet, the hops abscence, and the whiskey curiously weak. A little less than steller, but it does come across very clean and balanced; drinkable.

Bottle from Capones.  Pours hazy copper 2 2f ow head.  Nose is resiny hops, oaky bourbon, orange zest, floral.  Tastes of charred malt, oaky bourbion, hops, florals, gets some late heat, some late tannins, and almost reminds me of a vanilla iced tea mixed with brandy late.  The beginning is very good, though.

22 oz bottle served in a pint glass.  Pour is a deep, cloudy honey with about two fingers of white sudsy head.  Nose is oak, vanilla, and very light bourbon.  Taste is oak, bourbon, yeast, light vanilla, and bitter hops (though not piney) that bite into the finish.  This is a pretty tasty brew, nothing too skewed to make it one sided.  I especially enjoy the lack of the typical malt bomb that is often present in barrel aged ale.  It is light and refreshing, yet not along the lines of an IPA.  This is a very good change of pace.

An amber copper bock with a very thin white head. A sweet fruity aroma with light prunes and dark fruits, a bit of oxidation. In mouth, a bizarre taste of tar, wooden barrel, cardboard, rather oxidized, lingering alcohol burn, a bit of bilous hops, dark fruits. A bizarre beer, past its prime?  On tap at J. Ryans, May 2, 2010.

On tap at flying saucer. Pours a cloudy orange copper with a small frothy white head that diminishes quickly to nothing. The aroma is a light malt with caramel. Medium mouthfeel with a honey malt flavor. Hides the alcohol well making it easy to drink. A good Heller Bock from Rogue.
Hazy amber-orange, white cover.  Caramel, woody aroma.  Taste is Dead Guy with a light wood touch, kinda boring.

22oz bottle poured into a Shaker at 47°.  Color is a deep golden with good carbonation and a nice soft head.  Aroma is mild with malt, oak and vanilla.  Body is light with a crisp clean feel.  Flavor comes across light with a touch of vanilla on malt then a hint of oak with a very mild bitterness.  After taste lets the oak come out a bit more with a clean feel and a light lingering bitterness.  Overall its a very tasty, easy drinking brew.
I actually enjoyed this, I do like oak though. The oak notes left on the dead guy are quite strong, so may not be a beer for everyone.

this beer pours a rich amber with a large white head leaving some good lacing down the sides.  The aromas are bread, oak, and light citrus.  The palate is dry and lively with moderate carbonation.  really good brew!  Cheers!

3/03/2010:  Rogue John John Ale...  Aroma:  Smells like Dead Guy Ale (weak toffee malts; suggestions of citrusy hops) with some soft vanilla.
