Appearance:  Looks like Dead Guy Ale (light coppery orange color with an off-white to beige-colored head; nearly transparent; generous carbonation).  Flavor:  Pretty much like Dead Guy Ale, but comes across very yeasty with a dry, spicy, alcohol, whiskey-like finish.  Palate:  Medium-like, adequately carbonated.  Overall:  Yep, you guessed it...  This is pretty much just Dead Guy Ale, but slightly dry with just a little spike of whiskey; disappointing, but that isnt a surprise; weak.
12 fl. oz. bottle (40 IBU / 78 AA / 16 P / 16 L) shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #191 for this beer.
22 ounce bomber-a hazy orange pour-tan head-aroma and taste of caramel, whiskey,wood -sweet whiskey smooth finish

Bottle:  Pours a golden orange color with a finger of creamy beige head.  Modest aroma is malty, sweet, and lightly floral.  At first sip, a vein of bourbon shoots across my tongue in a syrupy, boozey blob.  I can barely pick up some faint earthy bits and maltiness before the lingering bourbon dominates the whole thing.  Blah.

Bottle and served in my NB Worthy glass: Deep amber hue with a lasting frothy head and spotty lace. The aroma has notes of herbal and grassy vapours, some vanilla bean, honey, oak, slight minerally and vile esters. The taste starts with notes of earthy and herbal overtones, moderate bitterness combined with light handed oaky whiskey tone. Seems a bit flat on the finish with a metallic aftertaste. The mouth feel is lively enough but that finish leaves something to be desired.  Simply a average overall brew that does not make me want to purchase again.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Total Wine Raleigh. 
It pours a deep copper color with a small, white head.  The nose is malty with some pale malt sweetness and a bit of wood.  The flavor is suprisingly gentle with notes of oak, vanilla, a bit of toasted malt, caramel, and a nice, light bit of whiskey in the end.  Other brewers should take note.  This is a subtle use of barrel aging that isnt overwhelming which makes the beer much more enjoyable.  Medium bodied with a dry, lingering whiskey finish.  A very drinkable brew that I would definitely recommend.  The success is in the subtleties of this one.

Dark amber pour with a frothy and lasting white head.  Aroma is malty with some wood/oak.  Flavor is caramel with some strong whiskeyish/boozy notes.  There is some light vanilla on the back end with a long, lingering sweetness.  Honestly, it takes exactly as I expected based on the bottle... its dead-guy aged in barrels.  Dead guy is pretty good, this is a bit better but not crazy outstanding.

22oz bottle. Pours a lightly hazed, orange colored body with a finger-width, off-white head that dissipates slowly leaving a thin layer of cream and a nice lacing. Aroma is fairly tame, but has a nice mixture of vanilla-bourbon, citrusy hops, and sweeter pale malts. Some sharper oak gives it a light wood too. Flavor is similar, but pretty jumbled. A bit too oaky and an odd mixture between the vanilla-bourbon and citrus. Thicker and sweeter pale malts try to balance this as some peppery spice and earth come in. Finishes dry with lots of oak and bourbon as well as some honey, vanilla, citrus, spice, and a moderate bitterness. Leaves a fairly lengthy aftertaste following a full, smooth body with a moderate carbonation. Goes down like a much higher ABV than 6.5%. Overall, not sure I like the barrel aging on this one. Doesnt seem to work right. Maybe a little cellaring would help.

Pours clear dark orange under a tall mostly white head.
The first aroma is fruity, some bubblegum.
Slightly sweet with a dry palate.
The barrel thing really doesnt hit you in the face with this one; almost hidden entirely.

Straight out of bottle so cant comment on color/head.  An inoffensive beer with a nice sweetness to it but the barrel aging that its gone through leaves it with an almost musty aftertaste that makes me not want to come back to this beer.  A little bit of hop background and a cloying quality over the palate.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a thick, tiny bubbled off white head, with some lacing, over a clear, light amber (SRM 7) body.....nose is vanilla, wood, whiskey, toffee/caramel.....taste is vanilla, whiskey, with a sharp woody (terpenes) finish, slightly sweet throughout.....mouth feel is medium and slightly sticky, carbonation adds a foamy character in the mouth. This beer has an almost turpentine like sharpness that I find off putting. This is a problem that wood aged, especially whiskey barrel, beers seem to have. It may simply be that they are released too young, and need more aging. I am not sure why it is listed as a Heller Bock. It could be an American Strong, or a wood aged beer. BJCP 6/3/12/4/6

Amber pour with small head. Aroma of resinous hops and big sugar. Flavt
or of a typical, basic, and boring iipa. No aging noticed. Dead hops. Cloyingly sweet. Finish is desert-like.

Rather clear amber orange. Really large head of mixed, foamy bubbles quickly dissipates and leaves just a few patches of lace. Nose is sort of musty with a bit of citrus. Lots of whiskey shows up once tasted, vanilla and maple being its predominant contributions. The bourbon taste is honestly very nice but this lacks a strong malty beer backbone to really hold it up. As it is, it tastes something like an uninteresting American pale ale w/ a touch of bourbon-based liqueur thrown in. I am a fan of barrel aging and think it has lead to some great beers, some of the best, but this is an example of why it should not be done indiscriminately.
Draft. Orange brown pour with some white head. Notes of whiskey, oak, perhaps some vanilla dominate over dead guys caramel malt and noble hop flavors.

Sampled on 2/26/2010. This heller bock pours an orange gold color from a paper labeled 22oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel, vanilla and oak. A medium bodied bock. The malts are caramel, semi-sweet with hint of orange, oak and vanilla. Touch of wood. Hops are earthy and floral. Nice carbonation. Hints of whisky and wood, mostly at the finish. The barrel aging effect are kind of subtle, perhaps some more time in the wood would have helped. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter, touch of whisky and a little boozy.
From a bottle poured an amber color with a fair amount of head.  Strong malty flavor with a lingering woody finish.

Wow. Its a Rogue Dead Guy aged in Dead Guy Whiskey Barrels and its exactly as advertised. If youve ever had a Rogue Dead Guy and wanted it aged in whiskey barrels, then this beer is for you. Rated 2/13/10
Bottle purchased at Rozis in Lakewood.  Flavor is a nice sweet malt, crisp fruity notes and a just a touch of aged smoothness.  Palate is crisp, sugary and very tastey.

22oz bottle. I really like this beer! Surprised it doesnt have more positive feed back. Pours out deep golden with a touch of amber to it. Aroma is great. its really soaked up the whisky aromas. Big vanilla character, oak, marzipan, really fruity too, kind of reminds me of a Pina Colada! Flavour is less intense than the nose suggests, and does a good job of not overpowering the beer itself, both are nicely harmonious. Flavour is malts and vanilla up front, then into the whisky, some orange notes, more marzipan, nore fruitiness, like dried apricot and peach flavours. Finish is nicely balanced between sweetness and dryness with a very subtle warm feeling coming from the whisky. Finish is whisky, vanilla. The beer finish is quite short, but the whisky persists longer with a nice dryness. Interesting beer made well in my opinion. TASTY!

Bottle at nimbleprop DC tasting, 6 March 2010. Im not a huge fan of Bocks at the best of times and I wasnt convinced that whisky barrel treatment would be a good idea. Or perhaps the whisky elements would combine well with the Bock to produce something more to my taste. As it was, I found the whisky influence rather subtle, perhaps adding a little vanilla and vinous notes. The overall impression was smooth and easygoing but I expected more impact. On the plus side, it was low on the sweet sticky malt character that I dislike in many Bocks. Pleasant enough but didnt really grab me.

(22oz Bottle) Pours a hazy orange color with an off white head. Smell is caramel malts, toffee, oak, and vanilla. Taste is caramel malts, toffee, vanilla, with some whiskey notes. Creamy medium mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Overall I really enjoyed this one.
Big Bottle, Honolulu. Fumes and dill weed. White head with little retention. Sweet taste. Does have oak and vanilla. I am glad I tasted and pairs well with Italian
Creamy aroma... vanilla oak flavor almost bourbony... definitely tastes like weak bourbon awesome flavor a little buttery nothing like dead guy... seems aged... creamy medium body...

Nice, warming aroma of whiskey with the underlying malt tones of dead guy coming through. Flavor is big on whiskey with vanilla oak followed by malt and a faint hint of hops. Overall very tasty, although a bit pricey.
Draught at Churchkey.  Clear bright amber, thin white head, decent lacing.  Aroma of malt and caramel.  Taste is vanilla and caramel with a slightly bitter finish.  Nice enough.

Bomber poured a clear amber with a lasting amber head. Aromas of whiskey, oak, carmel, vanilla and light fruittiness. Palatye was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of whiskey, oak, light carmel and light vanilla with a smooth finish. Fairly bland tasting, definitley not worth the price.

Draft at small bar. Clear orange-amber hue with a mostly dissipating white foam. Nose is vanilla coke with iced tea and sweet malt/woody accents. Flavor starts with a kick of cocoa crispies then transitions to vanilla and woodchips, midtaste sees a parade of sweet malts and tea leaves with low-med hop bitterness, finish dominated by cooling vanilla and fresh mint sweetness. Low-medium body, watery texture, moderate carbonation. Dead Guy with a twist, I think the crisp vanilla and cocoa tones compliment the light sweet malts well, dont know how this is the same abv as the base beer, bit kudos to Rogue on this variant!

Bottle. Amber beer with an off-white head. Sweet aroma with buttery malt and light whiskey. Whiskey and sweet malt flavor with oak and light earth. Medium bodied. Whiskey and oak lingers with sweet buttery malt.

Sampled from a 22oz bottle. Poured a dark amber color with a white head. Aroma was pale malts and caramel, with a good deal of vanilla. The flavor was pretty smooth, not too alcoholic, which was a nice surprise considering the "whiskey aging" which usually correlates with very high alcohol content.

Bomber pours a hazy amber body with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel, citrusy orange and pink grapefruit, and woodsy oak. Taste has more of a grassy and earthy hop bitterness than the aroma suggests. Pine and citrusy hop notes are also present. Caramel maltiness is equal to the task of balancing and also lends some brown sugar sweetness. Oaky wood adds a nice earthiness and the whisky emerges nicely as it warms. The subtle use of barrel aging works very well here. Just a bit edgier than the regular Dead Guy.

[Bomber Bottle] Pours reddish-golden with a small light beige head. Aroma is fairly weak--vanilla, whiskey, celery, sulfur notes, caramel and some alcohol. The off-notes arent great, but they disappeared quickly and overall it actually was pretty good. Taste is clover honey, marshmallow, decent bitterness, vanilla again, just the right amount of bitterness and a good malt backbone. Mouthfeel is medium-thin, average length finish. I dont know what to make of this. At first I was really underwhelmed, but it really grew on me. The barrel influence is pretty subdued, but otherwise this is very sessionable, and although it doesnt amaze, it is quite good.
On draft at Capones.  Pours a cloudy light carame lwith a medium sized frosty white head.  Aroma of light coconut, vanilla and whiskey.  Taste of light coconut, vanilla and whiskey.

16 ounce pint - $7.00 at Taco Mac in Woodstock, Georgia.

Appearance: Near clear, bronze body providing no real head formation beyond a scant white ring. Looks befittingly dead, I guess.

Smell: Aroma loaded with a dominating mediocre whiskey scent. Beneath the wood, the lighter vanilla, and overall fuming hotness are notes of glazed bread and toasted grains.

Taste: A befuddling scrambling of varying flavors in the taste. Sweet start of lightly toasted bready malts with light honey-toned accents are soon surged with Old Grand-Dad Whiskey. Touch of menthol. The whiskey is just a bit disproportionate to the underlying brew. Modestly hoppy, with a fair amount of bitterness and hints of citrus and spice. Coarse, hot, oaken finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-low carbonation.

Drinkability: Uncomfortably unbalanced. Honestly, its a bit tough to finish off. An accompanying glass of water was immediately requested. If someone had asked me what I thought would be the top ten best candidates for barrel-aging of any kind from the Rogue stable, DGA would have been absent from the list.

Deep golden brown with a big frothy white head. Aroma of caramel malts, honey, vanilla and oak. Slightly sweet. Toasted malts lead into whiskey, oak and hints of vanilla. Light earthy hop presence. Not bad.

Bottle sample at the Rogue tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 3/25/10. Pours clear amber with a medium beige head. Grainy malt nose with some citrusy hops. Malty flavor up front with some bitter hops and a subtle vanilla oaky finish. Very subtle on the oak and Im not sure I would have known this was an oaked beer without the label telling me so.

Pours a nice clear bittersweet orange with a fairly thick orangy-beige head that does not hang around too long. Aroma is yeasty and woody, slightly malty with a hint of smoke. Flavor is rich, malty, woody and a little yeasty with hints of smoke and sweetness. Texture is silky smooth and fairly fizzy, leaving a pleasantly woody finish.

22 oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a clear brownish amber color with a medium sized white head.  The aroma is lightly fruity, somewhat floral, sweet pale malts, vanilla, and light caramel.  The flavor is soft caramel malts, light vanilla, slightly woody with a touch of spice, and light whiskey notes in the finish.  There is not much in the way of the barrel with this and I think my money would be better spent on the regular Dead Guy.

On tap at the Rogue place in San Francisco. Pours a light brown color with a small white head. A sweet boozy nose, woody. The flavor is dominated by a light bourbon, woody, lots of sweet vanilla and caramel. Not bad.

Bottle/22oz. - Poured a hazy dark amber in color with a medium off-white head that stuck around for a while... very little lacing, however.  Aroma is malty and sweet with very little in the way of hops.  Flavor is surprisingly bitter with plenty of malty sweetness, but not overpowering.  Not much in the way of hop flavor.  The whiskey flavor definitely comes though and, for me, seems to work (unlike some others here).  Plenty of vanilla and oak in the flavor profile and in the finish.  I have never tried their whiskey, but I can already tell from this beer that I would like it a lot.  This was good...

Bottle.  Pours a clear ruby orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, bready malt, honey, and floral hops.  Flavor of whiskey plus the Dead guy malt.  Wow, the whiskey does NOT go well with the malt base!  What was Rogue thinking?  This was pretty disgusting flavor-wise.  
6/4/4/3/8 [2.5/5]

Pour is a clear, orangey-copper with an off-white, moderately full, and frothy head which leaves a very thin layer mostly throughout and leaves some sporadic lace.  Toasty, yeasty, bready malt and some citrus, almost berry-like, but also some spicy whiskey notes and light vanilla from the whiskey barrel.  Flavor is similar, toasty, bready, almost roast-like, and slightly sweet malts with vanilla and some spicy hops noted as well to match the spicy whiskey.  Palate is medium light, moderate carbonation, and a slick mouthfeel.  Finishes quickly with some spicy hops and a little toastiness with the whiskey barrels adding some desperately needed bitterness.  Interesting addition to the beer which I think improves the beer from a weird hybrid maibock ale base beer.

On tap at Cobblestones. Eh not too impressed. Faint malty smell and a flavor of watered down whiskey. No real beer character coming through. Thinking maybe a heller bock isnt the best candidate for barrel aging.

Poured honey color with decent sized head.
Aroma - sweet malt with hint of whiskey...and nice tropical fruit scent
Flavor - I really dig regular DG and this beer is no different! Has that great DG flavor with hint of whiskey and oak!
Palate - medium mouthfeel with syrupy texture. Carbonation is average and finish is dry. Aftertaste is somewhat boozey and lingers.
Overall - If you like DG and whiskey then you will love this beer. Warms the belly nicely!

From the bottle this poured clear amber orange with off white head, holding on for a little while, although no real lacing. Smells of caramel and some alcohol, mild vanilla and faintly of flowery hops. The flavors are very well balanced between the caramel maltiness and the whiskey characteristics. I get the woodiness of the barrels and some nice whiskey-like warmth.  A little bitterness up front opens the palate, then its a little syrupy and not too sweet. I say well done. Finishes clean.

(bottle - 22 oz) Clear gold pour with a thick white head. Very sweet and malty aroma with a ton of vanilla and oak notes. A good amount of whiskey flavor at the beginning followed up by a rather astringent and oaky malt middle. Some slight hops at the end but that bitter burn and bitter finish. A good attempt, but Im not really sure if a bock is the best beer to bourbon age.

Darker golden honey color white head .... aroma of sweet malt and whiskey .... taste of sweet caramel malts with a oaky whiskey kick in the finish .... just as it says dead guy aged in a whiskey barrel ... decent stuff
A heller Bock? really? I wouldve never guessed that. Pungent hoppy aroma, mixed with some mellow malty notes. Flavor is really heavy on the sweet, but finishes very clean. Tap @ The Thirsty Monk.

Pours a crystal clear amber with a big creamy beige head that recedes fairly quickly to a small cap and leaves spotty lacing.

Aroma has a hint of bourbon with some sweet vanilla on top of the underlying beer which features caramel malts and some toasted grains.  There are some light fruits as well - apples and pears come to mind.

The taste has a heavy dose of bourbon and seems sweeter overall than the aroma would suggest.  The caramel malts are more prevalent, as well as vanilla and oak.  The finish is very dry despite the sweetness of the flavors.

The mouthfeel is extremely smooth, but still dry and with plenty of bourbon in the finish.

Im not convinced this one is any better than the original as I dont know if the original beer is big enough to hold up to barrel aging.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2010 
Name: John John Dead Guy
Date: February 24, 2010
Mode: Bottle
Source: Bullocks
Appearance: clear copper, frothy off white head, sudsy lace
Aroma: dry and earthy aroma, spicy hops, hint of whisky
Flavor: dry caramel malt flavor, lots of earthyness keeps it dry, touch of oak, only a hint of wiskey, long bitter finish
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+ /4

Pours light amber with a thick beige head and a bourbon aroma. Tastes like Dead Guy with a whiskey chaser. There is some vanilla and oak in the finish. Its interesting, but a little raunchy. Lots of dead floaties at the bottom.

Nice strong head of small and dense bubbles.  Decent carbonation.  Nice aroma with some piney notes, light bourbon, toasted malts and a bit of butterscotch.  Color is a dark copper.  Smooth and easy drinking.  Very alcoholic flavor that really makes me doubt the 6.5% abv.  Lots of bourbon notes, butterscotch, caramel and some more pine.  A bit of hoppy bitterness.  Kind of dry and pasty the further you get to the finish of the beer.  Not that great and way too boozy for the body.

Just another rouge letdown.  Medicore whiskey notes flaw what was already a barely passing beer.  The barrel notes were totally overpowered and the dead-guy lacks enough character to carry the burden. Tsk-Tsk.  You should know better.
Slight malty aroma. Dead Guy...but where is the whiskey? Not getting the barrel aged at all. IPA with restrained hops.

22 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a clear amber color with a good size off white head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma is light toasted malt and light oak.  Flavor is toasted malt, oak/whiskey, and vanilla.  The oak/whiskey lingers a tad in the finish.  Medium body.  A nice beer.

On tap at Papago.  Pours a candy amber color with a trim off-white head.  Looks very unsuspecting.  Smells of the barrel, but faintly so.  Tastes oddly of mangoes, cardboard, and caramel.  Kind of weak, but I guess thats what you get when you barrel age a heller bock.

I didnt realize this was barrel-aged when I bought it - in hindsight, it makes sense, considering it was at least three bucks more for the bomber than every other Rogue product - my initial thought was, "heller bock in a whiskey barrel?  How about a rum barrel-aged pilsner while were at it!?" - the result isnt as bad as I was anticipating - the nose is of honey and coconut, with some vanilla and oak - flavor is of sweet caramel corn, whiskey, vanilla - some spicy, floral notes from the hops on the tail end - the whiskey isnt as overpowering as I expected, but this still isnt a style that seems to really work for the barrel-aging treatment - the whiskey just makes it "heavier" than you want it to be.

Bottle from Midtown at 10.49 plus tax. Ouch! Pours orange amber with a slight haze and a two finger beige dissipating head. Pronounced bourbon aroma. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Flavor is caramel and toasty malt that transitions to a strong flavor of heavily cut whisky. Tamed Vanilla and oaky finish. Not bad, but its missing something to make it more cohesive. Perhaps the barrel is just too overpowering with this beer. Hopefully they will do their XS stout with the barrels.

Bomber. A hazy orange/red in the glass, with a big white head that recedes to a little rim of tan. A sweet bourbon/maple/vanilla aroma, with some hints of orange and cinnamon - very pleasant. Flavor is fairly sweet and a little toasty, with some citrus notes and a little bitterness. Pleasant and easy to drink. A pretty enjoyable brew, really, and a fun concept.

22oz. brown bottle served in a Duvel Tulip. Poured a hazy, reddish gold with two fingers of off white head. Toffee in the aroma. Mild noble hop aroma. Oak really starts to come out in the nose as it warms. Medium bodied. Nice oak character with plenty of vanilla. Also a lot of butterscotch/toffee. Mild hop bitterness. Lots of whiskey character if you like that sort of thing (and I do). I really enjoyed this beer.

Bomber from Whole Foods Los Altos.  Pours a clear amber color with an off-white head and average retention.  Aroma is caramel malt, vanilla, wood, light fruits, and whiskey.  Smells pretty nice.  Flavor is dominated by the barrel notes.  I had my doubts about Rogue -bal aging such a subtle beer, but it actually didnt turn out too badly.   Flavor is whiskey, oak, vanilla, coconut, and tropical fruits.  Actually pretty well-balanced and tasty.  Highly drinkable, and thinking back on this beer, I would definitely enjoy it if offered again.  Not terribly exciting for a -bal aged beer overall, but really great for a heller bock.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2011 Sampled on draft at the Headkeeper in Greensburg PA this beer poured a dark caramel-amber color with a trace off white head. The aroma was fruity and woody. The flavor was moderately strong orange, wood, whiskey, nut caramel and pine. The finish was long with whiskey, orange, caramel and pine. Complex and rich. Full and thick body. Excellent.

Translucent amber, 1 inch almost white head. Thick and foamy. Sweet malty aroma. Maple and barley malt taste with plenty of left over sugar. A bit sweet although the bite is good. Oak finish, a bit abscured by the sweet malt.

Bottle.  Pours orange with thick off white head.  Good lacing.  Aroma of oak, vanilla, and light notes of bourbon.  Not expecting the aroma or flavor from the appearance.  Taste of Dead Guy Amber and finishes with bourbon and vanilla.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Good beer.

Pours an orangish amber, with ample white head. Complex and hoppy, with a bourbon barrel wood flavor. Some sweetness, with a nice and sharp finish. It is a good beer to drink slowly and savor. A thumbs up here.
Light aroma and a medium body. There is a nice malt flavor with a little spiciness. Nothing spactacular, but a nice drinkable beer.
Love the balance with the hop and vanilla sweetness but finishes a bit harshly. Still a great beer.

Really curious nose. Fermented honey and perfume, and something else I couldnt quite put my finger, er nose, on. Beer was smooth with a mild carbonation. Detecting some light corn and popcorn, unfortunately, but the stronger notes of honey and caramel do a good job of covering them up. Whiskey element is there, but it seems to be in the background, as are hints of wood and vanilla. Subtle yet solid zing of hops. Sweetness wins the battle in the end. Wood and a mild bitterness survives the finish. Overall, the beer has some oddness, but its not bad.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2010 22 oz. bottle from smith4498- thanks again, Jason!  Pours a cloudy gold-amber with reddish tints and plenty of sediment at the bottom.  Initially aggressive off-white head that settles into a small creamy cap on the beer.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, pale malts, and an artificial note that is sort of medicinal- that holds it back from being a really nice-smelling beer.  Some hops on the nose early but dont last.  Flavor is also big on bourbon, with vanilla and metallic and medicinal notes blocking other flavors.  Some malts and honey.  Medium-bodied with mild carbonation and a somewhat watery mouthfeel.  This could be a lot better but feels restrained in every element.

Pours hazy copper color with a cream colored head. Aromas of whisky, vanilla and oak.  Flavors of caramel, whisky, vanilla and oak. Sort of a medicinal aftertaste. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Bottle. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate roasted malt, vanilla and wood aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

Pours a very cloudy reddish color with a medium head and some lace. I will say that since I took notes on this Ive seen attractive pours of this beer so well average it out to a 3. The aroma is fruity and earthy. The flavor is more earthiness with a light oaky flavor some pineiness and some apricot, all of these things work alongside a nice strong hop bitterness. Not too bad.

Very nice version of DGA. Its that loveable rascal, the Hellerbock! Back to tickle us with its dryness, bedazzle us with its fruitiness and utterly sell us with its complex bitterness. Definitely whiskey barrel flavor makes this a sipper - comparable to that whiskey and soda one nurses throughout the evening. Yet this is as powerful as it is, but 6.5% - so it is the ultimate sipper, for a night where you need your head about you. Notes of tannin, oak, malt and smoke in this. Pours amber with thin white head.

22 oz bottle tasted blind on 3/11/10.  Pours orange with eggshell head.  Aroma of orange, pine, and a huge whiskey noze.  Flavor is a little sweet but dominated by whisky from front to back.  Also a bit boozy and tastes like carbonated whiskey.
Draft. Pours orange with a white head. Sweet malty aroma with some spicy notes. The flavor has sweet malts, spicy hops, and well restrained oaky bourbon notes. Well balanced.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2010 Opaque orange/amber color which is slightly cloudy. Head is off white and very thick creamy, with light sudsy lacing.  You can smell the oak right away in the aroma, followed by some orange, citrusy hops, and sweet caramel malt with hints of vanilla.  Excellent, complex nose on this beer.  Taste is very oaky, rich and creamy with a fantastic palate - reminds me of a nice smoky, single malt scotch but with a sweet start.  This beer is outstanding.

My Bottom Line:
Caramelized cereals, citrusy hops, wooden barrel notes and their spicy contributions coexist peacefully in this well executed but forgettable Strong Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam surrounds the hazy light amber.
-Carbonation is prickly, almost pushy.<br<
-For a brew in the 6% abv range, I would expect more drinkability. 
-The overall flavor profile is balanced.

Bottle.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2012 Warm honey pour with a thin, creamy, white head.  Nose is caramel malt and juicy apricot, complimented with a woody spirited note.  Flavor also reveals ripe peach, vanilla oakiness, and a surprisingly herbal-like finish.  The barrel aspects meld with the fruit notes to produce an orange-blossom creamed honey effect that I just love.  This subtle richness combines beautifully with the light herbal hops to make for a fantastic oaky/spicy finish.  This one just works for me.  This somehow mixes straightforward, drinkable (even at 8%) simplicity with subtle intricacy.  Not mind-blowing; but certainly nice and tasty.

Bomber. Probably from Bottle Barn in Santa Rosa, CA. Pours golden amber with a foamy beige head. Malty aroma. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Theres some whisky, vanilla, oaky aspects. Then caramel. Nothing much for hop bitter, I think, but the wood provides more than adequate bitter. Much better than regular Dead Guy.

aroma: caramel dark-sweet, lightly alcoholic.
appearance: browner honey
taste: woody, trace whiskey, gently hiding hop & malt
palate: light-medium
Tap. Clear orange pour with a thin white head. Aroma of pepper and grapefruit. Taste is similar, with some caramel and menthol. Just okay.

pours an amber color with medium white head.  Aroma is malt, vanilla and caramel.  Taste is vanilla, caramel and a hint of whiskey.  This is a decent beer, but not as robust as most oak aged beers.  Not sure how long they aged this one, but the mouthfeel leads me to believe its a much shorter aging than a typical beer.

Very slight haze to this orange to pale amber beer.  Not much head, even with vigorous pour.  Nose has some peach skin fruity aromas.  On the palate theres the immediately noticeable high abv, honey-malty flavors, some cough drop flavors, and then finishes with more malty sweet and alcohol warmth.

Bomber.  Pours a highly carbonated amber with a one finger off-white head.  The nose is  vanilla, citrus and caramel.   The taste is citrus, oaky vanilla, caramel and floral hops.  Medium bodied.  Not picking up much bourbon, but decent brew regardless.

Enjoyed via draft in a pub glass.  The beer pours a hue that is essentially identical to unoak-aged Dead Guy.  The initial nose is very subtle (read too slight).  After lots of sniffs and swirling, the drink begins to reveal itself, but still only very slightly.  Grassy hops, caramel, and a bit of whiskey-like alcohol character.  The palate is also more subtle than regular Dead Guy.  It still shows some malt sweetness, but it is clearly dialed back in its intensity.  Again, some caramel and Munich malt flavors.  The finish is slightly fruity and floral, perhaps the result of some added complexity due to barrel aging.  Being a big fan of regular and double Dead Guy, I had high hopes for this beer.  Unfortunately, it is a disappointment of the first order.

Pours a deep amber haze with an off-white soapy head.  Smells and tastes exactly like you would expect a 2IPA blended with wisky to taste.  I enjoy wiskey cannot say I love it.  Interesting brew nonetheless.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers, apricot), with notes of vanilla, cotton candy, wood.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

It actually ends up pretty much how it sounds...Dead Guy with some woody character.  The wood is a bit sawdusty, but there is some vanilla in there as well.  Not bad, but rather plain.

Another attempt from the over-priced guys at Rogue to make something "different".  Nice hints at whiskey and what not, but overall I was expecting a lot more full of a beer.  Bit too watery.  Maybe that isnt what they were going for...regardless, the best thing about this was that it was MUCH cheaper than expected from these guys...
Light malt and whiskey aroma. Hazy brown color with a small tan head, Bitter beginning developing into a oak bite finish.
slightly cloudy amber with a decent head.  nose has notes of vanilla and oak over some caramel malt and light hoppiness.   taste is a smoother dead guy with vanilla and oak at the finish.
(bottle) deep amber with eggshell head. Aroma was whiskey. Taste was dominated by whiskey. Too unbalanced for my tastes.

bottle.  clear medium copper, off-white head.  very quiet nose: honey and cracker malts, minerally/gravel-like pacman yeast, a bit soapy.  very faint tough of whisky and wood, very quiet throughout, honey sweetness up front, mild minerally yeast, light tough of whisky/rum/something in the back.  pretty forgettable overall.

On tap at Breakwater. Pours amber with a thin, offwhite head that leaves good lace. Smells malty and sweet with a nice dose of whiskey. Tastes like Dead Guy all the way through until the finish when the whiskey hits. Malty and sweet, plain overall. Whiskey on the finish. Medium body, good carbonation.

Tap @ Trappeze.  Poured a deep copper gold, with a nice off white head.  Aroma of nice bourbon notes of oak, vanilla, and booze.  Some aromas of sweet malt as well.  Taste is similarly vanilla, oak, malty, with some bready notes and little grain.  Mouth is full bodied and creamy.  Overall, a nice brew.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market, poured into lager glass. Golden amber color and cloudy with an off-white head. Aroma was full of whiskey and butterscotch with a hint sourness. Taste was unpleasantly sweet. Tasted more like sour mash than whiskey; lots of corn and butterscotch. Full-bodied and creamy. I dont think Id try this one again.

22oz from Hope Valley Bottle Shop. For some reason I was expecting very little from this one, and I found it a pleasant surprise. Somewhat cloudy amber pour with the moderate creamy head, just as youd expect from Dead Guy of course. But the light whiskey and wood in the nose - more subtle than anticipated - worked really well with the malts. Creamy mouthfeel and again, the barrel complements the flavor quite nicely, but not (thankfully) at the expense of the hop presence. Nice one.
Not too bad. Nice barrel character. Just a bit of a strange medicinal note in the finish and very tannic.

22oz bottle DC local tasting.  Clear amber orange with a creamy, white head.  The nose is all barrel, a little caramel and butterscotch, but the nose is pretty much watery down scotch.  Flavor is all barrel, a little butterscotch and vanilla... but where is the maibock?  Finish is a little harsh.  Weird and unbalanced.

Draft sample @ Brewvival on 2/27/10.  deep copper pour... slight whiskey nose - would like more out of this... some caramel malts... doesnt really stand out for me as a nice barrel aged beer... somewhat lacking.

Poured from bottle. Nose is toast, yeast, and fruit -- too mellow to be citrus, too light to be fig or raisin; closest I can get is kiwi. Color is a vibrant orangey gold with a long-lasting head and noticeable lace. Flavor is toast, spice, vanilla, and dark fruit; you can really taste the whisky influence, but it doesnt come off as unpleasantly boozy or hot. The finish is caramel, smoke, and a touch of hops. This is damned good stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2010 Bomber from Bruisin. Copper color with a small head. Aroma is rich of balanced bourbon notes of wood and vanilla. Pleasing lager tones of burning leaves and crisp veggies are an afterthought. The flavor matches up with a balace of cereal, wood, and a creamy vanilla body. The annoying gummy flavor I associate with bocks and makes me dislike Dead Guy is kept to a minimum in John John.  This is way better than Dead Guy.
Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  The look is clear, golden in color, and has a white head.  The smell is corn, bourbon, paint, and wood.  The taste is whiskey, wood, malts, and grains.

Pours a light golden color with thin off-white head.  Aroma is of a funky cheese smell which is not great at all.  Taste is a lot better then the aroma, thank god.  Light caramel and sweet malt matched with some vanilla and light oak.  Still, this beer feels janky and rough around the edges.  It certainly is not worth the $9.99 I paid for it.

Thanks for sharing, bro!  Pours a slightly cloudy golden color with a medium off-white head which leaves a decent amount of webbed lacing.  Aroma is slightly cheesy, biscuit, light maple syrup.  Taste is light malt, biscuit, light citrus, and some caramel and maple.
has very little head - down to lacy very quickly. Apricot and mild-sour flavors. The aroma is unusual. A little alcohol-y.
The vanilla and oak really come through on this. Not much hop to it which is a bit surprising, but a pleasant, smooth drink.

Pours hazy copper-amber into the glass, with a small cap that leaves wash lacing.  True bourbon whiskey (Makers Mark/Jim Beam) abounds in the bouquet.  The flavors are completely overwhelmed by a bourbon essence.  It starts off as a dry caramel malt with just a hint of biscuit, some vanilla follows mid-palate, and some dry-hopping at the finish gets a whooping kick of bourbon sting (and effervescence) to close the pull.  Not boozy, per se, because the mouthfeel is quite lighter than I wouldve thought for such an array of whiskey characteristics.  A bit pungent on the tongue, it has an active texture surrounding a medium body.  All-in-all, it is a different brew, and a rather interesting one to rate.  Decent, but a truly "special" occasion offering.
22oz bottle.  Small off-white head atop hazy amber body with dead yeast.  Aroma is moderately sweet, Bourbon/vanilla, caramel.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some Bourbon/vanilla.  Medium body.

Tap at CAH.  Pours a lightly hazy golden with light amber notes and a smaller bubbly white head.  Aroma of booze, oak and a dead...dead guy ale.  Flavor of cheap whiskey, oak, vanilla that kills the dead guy.
Draft at brewvival.   Hazy gold pour with a fluffy white head and drippy lace.  Aroma is booze, vanilla, and caramel.  Flavor is spicy, sweet and boozy.  On the verge of being cloying.  Hot

on tap at Coles, Buffalo NY. golden orange pour. hints of oak, vanilla, rich maltiness in the aroma. taste is oaky whiskey upfront, rich maltiness follows. Pretty good. whiskey flavors lingers on the palate

Pours a tan burnt-orange with a moderate white head.  Aroma of toast, leafy hops, toffee, orange, and almonds.  Flavor starts with some wood and toast then sweetens up with caramel, vanilla, toffee, and tea-like hop presence.  Subtle nutty wood, whisky notes. Finishes with toast, caramel, wood, almonds and a subtle whisky note.  Medium bodied but slightly thicker and richer flavored than Dead Guy.  Its a VERY welcome sight to see some non-high alcohol barrel-aged beers, but will refuse to give Rogue credit for this.  And the barrel qualities are very far from overdone.  Good!

22oz bottle shared by Sean (DuffManSW). Rating #81. Dark gold and a little orange tint as well and a dirty white head. Very malty with a nice little hint of whiskey and light hops. Flavor was similar very subtle whiskey and some wood and nice clean maltiness, real good beer. (1147)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: (22oz bottle, courtesy of ilovedarkbeer)  Pours a clear amber body with a medium cream head.  Aroma of wood, whiskey, and vanilla.  Flavor of vanilla, wood, grass, and caramel malt with a dry finish.

22oz. bottle.  Toasty, sweet caramel aroma, lightly oaky and fruity with notes of apricot, vanilla, honey, melon and some faintly citric, floral hop.  Hazy medium golden-amber color, head is fine and lasting.  Flavor profile begins with a blend of spicy, grassy, fruity hop flavors and moderate bitterness, fading to reveal toasty caramel malt sweetness and golden raisin, finishing semi-dry and oaky with hints of honey and vanilla.  Perceived whiskey character is fairly minimal.  Gently carbonated and somewhat crisp palate, body is medium.  Rather tasty.
Bottle...Pours orange golden with a thin white head...slight coconut aroma with very subtle barrel aging..Flavor is coconut, vanilla verry nice...I really like this one.

Bomber. 
Light amber with a tight tan head above lively carbonation. A thin layer of sticky lace coats the glass.
Aroma is decidedly caramel, but a vigorous swirl brings out a blast of vanilla. 
Flavor begins sweet, but as it warms it takes on a whiskey character, boozy with an oaky dryness. 
Long dry oaky finish.

The aroma of whisky and sweet malts with a yellow honey ruby sunset appearance describe this beer. The flavor starts out sweet and then the boozy whisky flavors from the barrels follows throughout the palate. Not my cup of brew with the absence of sweet flavors.

whats the abv on this bad boy? Had a nip from a friends bottle.  Great aroma and character where the whiskey really shines through without being overwhelming.  At 9 dollars a bomber, I won;t be buying this one, so probably won;t try it ever again, but it is pretty tasty if you have no qualms spending that much.

I was a fan of the original Dead Guy.  This does not substantially improve upon it.  The aroma is bread, caramel, leafy hops, and a mild whiff of whiskey.  The appearance is a hazy orange, off-white head.  The flavor is bread, earthy hops, light whiskey.  The finish is a earthy hop bitterness.  The mouthfeel is a little thin and carbonated.  In fact, I dont like this as much as Dead Guy.  At least they dont commit the offense of allowing the whiskey to dominate the beer (as so many Barrel aged beers do these days). This is a passable beer, but not the great beer the Dead Guy is.

A decent version of Dead Guy. Wasnt a big fan of the original but this makes it a little better. Aroma was decent but kind of faint. Vanilla and oak in the distance. Pour was a nice dark gold with a two finger off white head. Taste was very mellow which is actually a good thing. Woody and vanilla in the front with just a faint notion of whiskey in the aftertaste. Some caramel comes out as it warms and blends well with the vanilla. Nice carbonation. Wouldnt buy again but glad I tried it.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Sampled at Binnys Glen Ellyn, IL. After Dinner Tasting. Poured into a small snifter a hazy, orangy amber, with modest, off white, bubbly foam, and light lacing. Maybe due to a combination of esters, phenols, and cask wood, my initial review of the aroma found a fleeting wisp of naphalene. As I eased into my next try, I sensed some spiciness and ripe orange, or more tangerine rind. The flavor mimicked this fruity note, and presented a medium bitterness, somewhat light body, and average carbonation. Too style perplexed to go into more detail or search for more notes. Not terrible, and might try again to settle my inquisitive nature as to whether or not some infection/oxidation was present.
smells of caramel and alcohol. Orange  amber in colour with a little white lacing. tastes of vanilla , caramel and whiskey.  A nice drinkable beer.
bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  poured goldish with a white head.  aroma was pine, musty, orange, and bourbon.  flavor was pine, floral, and bourbon with a light body and medium carbonation.
Bottle. Had a lite whiskey aroma, soft head and a bit sugary. Decent sipper.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2010 Draft at The Sanctuary. Poured a clear medium orange color with an off white head. There was a touch of whiskey on the nose accompanied by whiffs of toffee, molasses, oak, and even chocolate. Medium bodied and dryish with relatively high carbonation. Mild bitterness emerged at the end. The whiskey and oak were there, but these flavors were not overpowering. I liked this much better than Dead Guy which I find really overrated.

Burnt tangerine color with a nice eggshell head that left some sticky lacing.  Aroma shows roasted malt, vanilla, honey, and a bit of wood.  Flavor is well balanced with the caramel malt playing well with both the barrel and background hops.  The whiskey is subtle, very subtle in fact, but adds a bit of complexity and interest.  Medium mouthfeel.  Pretty good beer by Rogue.

pours a clear amber with a medium size off-white head, and some lacing.

smell is floral, a slight amount of citrus, caramel, and malt.

taste is creamy, malt, butterscotch, a tad sweet, caramel, and hops found in the back, ends smooth, and a little dry.

pours a very clear caramel/amber color with a medium lt. tan head...great retention and lacing!  aroma has lt. vanilla and whiskey with cocnuts and cream...sweet and assertive but not phenolic.  flavor has a nice subtle whiskey flavor up front with faint vanilla and crisp, spicy hops...maybe some oak?  also some light caramel malt flavor.  mouthfeel is lighter than i expected...very lively with a dry, lingering finish.  though it looks and smells bettter than it drinks, it is a very nice beer...one of the best rogues ive had.
Pours a light copper color with white head. Aroma is caramel, toast, fruity, some bourbon, some oak, and floral. Flavor is caramel, vanilla, oak, some bourbon, floral, and a bitter spicy flavor.

22oz bottle.  a clear light orange under a large fluffy off-white head.  not a super strong aroma.  flavor has mild barrel notes and  still has the rogue hoppiness.  a bit of caramel, marshmallow, vanilla.  the palate is the bees knees....so silky smooth.  im kinda diggin this a lot.

Pours cloudy brown with a thin head.  Light aroma, mixture of citrus hops, wood, whiskey, and some malt.  The flavor was alright, blended well, but nothing really stood out at me.  The whiskey aroma and flavor was very light.  Slightly sweet.  Decent, but I was expecting a little more.

Pours a very clear, deep orange with red hues in the sun light. Head is very tall, white and small bubbly that fades down at a modest rate. Aroma has a strong grassy hops note with a light woody and mild toasted malt presence. Flavor has almost no notes very early but then the flavors creep up later in the tasting. The hops for this brew provides a very grassy flavor that combines with the low toasted malt character later in the tasting. Very mild caramel notes come through at the tail end. Body is light with very high carbonation which creates a very dry feeling at the end. Overall I was a bit disappointed. Almost no whiskey or oak character were carried into the brew. The grassy hops flavor was strong for only a 40 IBU brew and the dryness created on your tongue made it very difficult to pick up the finishing flavors.

22 oz. bomber from Greens on Ponce De Leon. Nice fluffy head. It wasnt that difficult to produce a head on this thing. It (the head) seems to be fading away rather slowly. Copper colored beer. For a heller bock, this is looking pretty good. Sweet honey, caramel, sugar, and wood are hitting my nose. This beer is not pungent at all! My nose is having to dig deep in order to get anything from this. A slight citrus fruit taste coming through. I have this happen to me every time I have certain barrel-aged beers i.e. I can taste citrus fruit. Caramel malt flavor and sugar are hitting my taste buds. Vanilla flavor is sporadic, but there. A slight bitter touch towards the end. Meh... this thing falls flat in terms of uniqueness and bold flavors and aromas. I am enjoying this, but only slightly.

Fruitylaced malt ,almost of a melon nature,some hop zing, quickly followed by a caramel and then a wood nature. It was amazing how one aroma would become evident,totally fade and another appear. By the aroma ,I couldnt tell that this sat in whiskey barrels. Flavor is totally different,mild sweet citrus hops , sharp grainey malting,but now the whiskey is in the forefront, solid woodgrain whiskey,mild but distinct,after a swallow,the aftertaste is like I took a straight shot of medium grade whiskey about two minutes ago. Glad I tried a bottle

clear copper colored pour with a dense white head. Earthy aroma. Like most rouge ales that are infused with a flavor, the whiskey barrels really impart a distinctive taste, which is paired perfectly with the malt. Finishes semi sweet. really flavorful beer

From tap at Rogue Ales Public House in SF. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is smooth fruity, hoppy and light wooden. Smooth fruity, light brett-ish and dry hoppy flavoured. Bitter and smooth fruity finish. Nice one.

Pours a copper brown color with a little haze and a white head. Aroma is watered down whiskey, a hint of oak, caramel, spices. A note on the aroma is that it is very subtle, it doesnt jump out like a lot of bigger barrel aged beers. Flavor is almost like watered down dead guy, with some hop bitterness and harshness that meets half way with oaky tannins and watered down whiskey. But it works because the whiskey isnt overpowering the dead guy. Lots of subtle oak and hop nuances in the finish of this one. Reminds me of the barrel aged brewdog IPA in some ways because its so watery despite the obvious difference in styles. Interesting experiment, not fantastic but worth trying.

Bottle thanks to Jason!  Light brown pour, small whitish head.  Malty and hoppy aroma, maybe some toothpick aroma, but where is the barrel?  Flavor is malty sweet with a good citrus hop bite, but again where is the barrel? Id rather have regular old dead guy.

22oz bottle from Olive Tree Market.  Pour is lightly hazed copper with a small off white head, some spotty lacing.  interesting nose of sweet peaches, dry oak and whiskey.  Also a good amount of peaches and other tree fruits in the flavor.  Has that strange whiskey esk palate that makes you feel like youre already hung over.  A very interesting brew, still like Dead Guy better on its own.

This brew is beautiful. A deep apricot/amber color with a decent head that lingers while cold and disappears when warm. Smells of stonefruit and perfume. Full nectar with creamy carbonation. Semi sweet with stonefruit, citrus, defined whiskey, baked biscuits, and good acid. The finish is bittered with a nice hop profile. The brew never goes sweet and keeps its balance. Good whiskey, not overbearing. A fine brew with a luscious mouthfeel. Great job!

22oz bottle poured into Chimay goblet.  Copper color with 1 inch head which dissipates quickly.  Smells of floral hops and citrus.  Great first tasts.  Hints of whiskey, citrus, pineapple and coconut.  Not very hoppy like the smell.  Medium carbonation and smooth.  I really enjoyed this beer.

orange copper colour with a thick head.
aroma is muted pale malts and light woody whiskey.
Flavour carries a lot of whiskey tones. buttery woody tones, light alc, vanilla and caramel. light hoppy bitterness. 
An interesting permutation of Dead Guy.

22oz bottle, no date from Bottle Barn--$8.99.  Clear medium amber with a short-lived, one finger off-white head to a thin film.  Light whiskey and vanilla dominate the aroma with a little toast and sweet caramel malt, hints of honey.  Not a very strong smell.  Flavor has stronger whiskey, vanilla, and oak notes that actually complement the caramel and light toasty grain nicely.  Not a lot of sweetness to be had, but the barrel and hop bitterness keep it balanced.  Semi-dry with bitterness at a 3, no alcohol burn (dunno its strength, but regular Dead Guy is sixish--so cant be too much stronger).  Light prickly carbonation with a medium body.  Not too bad, but not much fancier than Dead Guy with booze.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: On tap at Capones. Poured an amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of some woodiness, very light whiskey, and some vanilla. Tastes of wood, vanilla, lighter whiskey, and some lighter hoppiness.
Pours orangeish amber with a white head. Aroma light oak,  sweet malt, and a little vanilla. Flavor is lightly sweet, a bit of oak, bitter, slightly astringent finish.
bottle, orange colored pour with thick tapioca foam, aromas of malty dried fruit, flavor is some metallic hops and thick fruit with a weak finish
Tasted at Extreme Beerfest. Dark gold color, off white head. Smooth beer, but not as much flavor as I had expected. I think this might be over-hyped.

22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma  Hoppy with good malt backing very little to no Bourbon aroma.
Appearance  Dark amber in color, clear with a thin head. 
Flavor  Roasty malt with a good backing of hops this beer then died no Barrel or Whiskey flavoring to speak of.  
Palate  Dry overall finish with s nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall  I just did not get the flavors this beer was promoting.  No Whiskey or Barrel aging.  This brew was like a regular Deadguy and in fact was a tad flat.  Sorry Do Over is in need on this brew.  Very much disappointed with this beer.

From a 22 oz bomber that set me back $10.  This pours a clear dark amber with a good sized off-white sudsy head and moderate lacing. . The nose is of whisky  Medium body and crisp mouthfeel. The flavor is caramel malts and a lot of the whisky.  The finish is strongly alcoholic.  Overall this just seems like Dead guy with some whisky poured in. There is something not integrated here, and the end result simply does not hang together Drinkable, but barely.  For sure not worth the price.

Bottle. Slightly hazed amber. Rocky, frothy white head. Aroma is vanilla, sweet malt, caramel, spicy notes and candy. Taste is oak, vanilla, sweet malt, caramel, candy, spicy hops, light toffee and soft alcohol. Body is soft carbonation throughout a medium mouthfeel. Finishes with more vanilla, oak, whiskey, candy, light fruit, sweet malt, caramel, and spicy notes. rather tasty. Rogue has impressed me with the last few beers of theirs Ive tried.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours a rich, honey brown with a tremendous, billowing, subtly off-white head. Aroma is absolutely amazing; the aging in whiskey barrels is immediately apparent. Nose of sweet malts, honey, vanilla, barley, molassess, melted butter, and just a slight touch of hops. Fuller bodied with a nice, round, robust mouthfeel. Slightly sticky. Sweet, but not saccharin, and just the right amount of carbonation. The ratings for this brew are tragically low. A truly lovely, well-crafted beer from Rgoue. Highly recommended.

Sample at Rogue Ales Distillery & Public House. The beer is a clear orange-amber color with a medium thin white head that diminishes steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of dried fruits, bready malt, and bourbon. Medium body with flavors of caramel malt, fruit, vanilla and bourbon. The finish is fruity with a boozy and malty aftertaste. Does a good job of retaining the elements of Dead Guy with the added character of the barrel aging. We did try the beer again at the Newport location and found it a lot more muted and less enjoyable, but in Portland it was really good.

Sampled at the 2010 Crescent Moon Extreme Beer Festival. Light amber with a medium ivory head. a delicate looking beer. the mild aroma has serious elements of a smooth bourbon. The flavor is mild. but there is not much here. Its boring, in fact. Its overrated. I am glad I did not purchase the bottle.

On tap at Stub & Herbs. Poured a clear dark yellow amber with a thin opaque head. Aroma has notes of sweet grains, caramel and a touch of whiskey. Flavor was a bit more subdued with a note of grain and an undertone of alcohol throughout.

22. Pours a crystal clear golden brownish dark amber with a loose off white sudsy head. Lots of whisky on the nose--too much, really; its sharper and twangier than it needs to be, and this beer wont stand up to the kind of aging that would be required to mellow these volatiles. Toast and caramel under that. Creamy medium body, active carb, and eyelid-fluttering alcohol heat. Quite vaporous and acetic. Toast, caramel, vanilla, vodka, and scorched wood on the mid-palate. Long toasty vodka finish. Not sure what the big idea was here, but its hard to believe this is what they had in mind.

I expected so much more. I love fresh DG after working for the brewery for a time and this tasted just like fresh DG with a mere hint of the whisky. I wanted more of a boozy flavour, but it was barely there.
Amber pour. Nose is earth, dusty baking chocolate, and vanilla. Taste is the same with additional nutty caramel. Uninspiring.

hazy tangerine pour with fizzy lean carb and film head. flavor is far more whiskey then wood, no booze component can be attributed to anything but pure whiskey flavor. intrincially that spirit has a wood element but the flavor here is pure liquor.  flavor is warm fire and a hit of smoke, utterly enjoyable for any whiskey drinker.   backnote is raisin, aroma is largely fruity malt note minus the big booze lying beneath awaiting the palate. one of the more interesting uses of BAing ive come across and a pleasant 666th rating.

65 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Slightly hazy apricot colour, frothy long lasting head. Honey, caramel and a faint bourbon aroma. Mildly carbonated, first sip is all whiskey, mellow, with a bread, nut and vanilla finish.

bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  light amber with a white head.  light vanilla, malts but im not getting much else off the nose.  very light on the palate with flavors of malt, grass, wood and a slight vanilla finish.

( 22oz bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer) Pours clear orange with nice oily bubbles and great lacing. Nose of whiskey, sweet corn and bread, candied fruits, and some vinous notes. Taste of alcohol, sweet bread with a creamy body that is quite hot on the finish. Fruity notes linger on the palate and a medium body.

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Clear light orange pour with a small white head. Aroma is clove, orange peel, lemon, bourbon. Flavor is brown sugar, whiskey, lemon, tangy. Dry finish with low carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours an orange body with a white head.  Oak and vanilla notes, some light leather tones with hints of dry herbal hoppiness.   A dry woody toned sweetness still dry and light like leather.  A spritzy hoppiness vanilla and a hint of honey sweetness with a modest warming.  A decent ale.

Thanks Justin!  Medium honey in the glass, some sharp alcohol on the nose.  Both products are distinct here and have yet to marry fully.  More time?  Some of the delicate fruit notes in the Dead Guy are lost in the aging, masked by the whiskey.  I get too much raw alcohol surrounding the beer to fully love it.

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a very nice looking murky, deep amber with nice beige head. Aroma is malty with notes of wood. Flavor is sweet, malty, little spiciness, wood, light caramel and a touch of whiskey. Mouth feel is heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, I very much enjoyed this!

Copper with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of coconut, vanilla, wood, caramel malts, nuts, toast, and light whiskey.  Taste of sweeter caramel malts, wood, vanilla, and a semi-sweet finish.

Pours a transparent copper amber with a clingy-lacing off-white head.  Aroma of semi-sweet grainy caramel and maize with a touch of butterscotch and whiskey.  Starts with decent fullness and a well-dissolved carbonation with some grainy corn notes and semi-sweet light caramel malts before a drier, slightly warming finish.  It doesnt seem like the heller-bock style has meshed that well with the whiskey flavors.  Probably wouldve been better off putting Shakespeare Stout in the whiskey barrels.

650 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a slightly cloudy copper color with a small white head that dissipates to a fine film.The aroma is distinct with  perfume, spice, florals and whiskey. The taste is whiskey forward with a distinct, but watered down, bourbon character. The floral notes detected in the nose are evident as part of the whiskey base. Also present is a bit caramel and some biscuit. The palate is full and malty with lively carbonation. The finish is long and dry with lingering salty bourbon. Overall: A very interesting and tasty concoction.

Bottle courtesy of ilovedarkbeer. Clear golden yellow with small sediment. Big sweet smell with citrus notes. Small oaky notes. Sweet flavor that leaves an alcohol burn. Slight whisky flavor. Finishes with maltedness. Dry finish.

Nose is a little weak. Some orange juicy notes - a touch over the hill perhaps, light wood and a hint of whiskey. Pours hazy golden with a thin touch of head. The flavor is light whiskey notes, woody barrel, sweeter fruity malts, and a touch more orange juice. Interesting beer to age in a barrel. Thin and not much going on to make it that interesting.

Had a 5 oz. sampler at Capones. A complex beer that has a noticeable change in character as you drink more. Starts out primarily hoppy, but gets more of a smooth whiskey flavor the more you drink. I liked this.

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  Body pours a clear, honey/copper with a small off-white head.  Aroma is oaky, some floral hops and light malt semi-sweetness.  Taste is young oak, light caramel sweetness, whiskey, lightly roasted malt.  Lingering mild hop bitter.  Medium mouthfeel and carbonation.

Thanks to ilovedarkbeer for sharing this bottle.

Pours golden orange with a white head. The aroma is fruit with some whiskey and vanilla. The flavor is whiskey and oak with some vanilla and fruit. The oaked character of the beer really comes through in the flavor. Medium, creamy mouthfeel and carbonation.

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Pours with an off-white head and a slightly hazed orange body. Aroma is sweet with unfermented sugar and light oak. Taste is soggy grain, and underneath it some dry wood and whiskey notes. Creamy carbonation but a dry finish. Leaves myself asking, "why?".

Draught at Capones:  Faint aroma of whiskey and a hint of oak.  Poured orange/amber in color with a large, creamy, dense, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Lightly sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of whiskey, oak, vanilla, and slight bitter hops.  Medium body.  Average carbonation.  Whiskey, oak, and hop finish is lightly sweet.

Bottle pours semi-clear orange color with white head that doesnt last long.  Aroma is very subtle whiskey notes.  I had to smell this a couple times to make sure I was getting it right it was so subtle.  Medium light mouthfeel.  Almost watery.  Not good for a BA brew.  Flavor was a bit 1 dimensional.  The malt base is pretty much non existent and there is a smooth whiskey profile that finishes somewhat dry.  I get the oak, vanilla, some orange like flavors from grand marnier, and it has the makings of an amazing brew.  But it disappoints.  In a big way.  I give this an average rating because its about as average as you can get.  Which for me is a big disappointment because most beers that are barrel aged are so complex.  Too bad this one is pretty plain.

Bomber.  Poured clear, honeyed orange with a short, fizzy-ish cap of off-white head.  The aroma picked up vanilla beans, honey, and sweet caramel laced with tangy oak and light whiskey.. soft, slick, and sweet overall.  The flavor found the same vanilla, honey, and caramel at the core, with a greater whiskey and tangy oak presence around.. sharp oak and lightly bitter earth on the edges.. whiskey, vanilla, and caramel on the finish.  Medium-bodied and very slick on the palate.. low carbonation.. the whiskey stuck for a little while on the sweet finish.. this wasnt bad, but it really seemed uninspired.

Tap at Fiddlers.

Relatively light pour with an ample head. Boozy nose, the alcohol fumes washing out most anything else beyond a general syrupy sweetness.  Mouthfeel is thin and hot, with the heat probably more an illusion from the whiskey fumes than from the alcohol. Somewhat pleasant sweetness to the flavor, a relatively nice change to have whiskey-aged beer that isnt over the top on the oak, but ultimately there is not enough going on here in the flavor profile to make up for the other deficiencies.

Bottle. Moderate roasted and cereal for the malt, herbs for the hops, light soap for the yeast, with hints of cask wood in the background. Head is fizzy, off-white with no lacing and is mostly diminishing. Flavor starts moderately acidic and finishes lightly sweet, moderately acidic and heavily bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery with a fizzy carbonationa and very dry and lightly astringent finish. This Heller Bock has a huge hop profile. I would think with the barrel aging this would have been much mellower than Dead Guy, but its quite bitey.

Bomber from Binnys in Downers Grove, Illinois:  Basically, it looks, smells, and tastes like Dead Guy Ale aged in a whiskey barrel for, oh, one week, maybe two.  Its got an amber/orange body with a tall white head that provides plenty of lace.  The aroma is sweet and caramelly with a touch of stone fruit and a whole lot of booze.  The flavor is sweet and caramelly with a touch of stone fruit and a whole lot of booze.  A touch of woody dryness comes in at the finish.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy rust color with a HUGE light-tan head that leaves chunks of lacing behind.  A subtle aroma with hints of caramel and honey.  Thin to medium-bodied.  The flavor starts with some touches of caramel and honey.  Finishes with just a bit of citrus and a gently drying, crisp biscuitiness.  The slightest bit of vanilla imparts some smoothness throughout.  Not a bad beer, just not a whole lot going on here at all.
Pours golden with a small white head.  Aromas of caramel and whisky.  Flavors mimic the aromas.  Finishes dry with a slight bitterness.

Bottle 22oz tasting at work.  Not bad.
Aroma is a light blend of vanilla, caramel, and whisky.
 Appearance is an amber pour with some haze and a minimal white head with little to no lacing.
 Taste opens up the nose more, but is still lighter than what one would expect from a whiskey aged beer. Slight sweet start finishes bitter with a whiskey backbone.
 Light body with a creamy texture and average to soft carbination on the palate.  Finish, as mentioned, is medium long and slightly bitter with more notes of vanilla, caramel, and whisky.
  Overall, it isnt what you would expect from a barrel aged beer, but the flavor of both the beer and whisky backbone are a welcome combination.  I wouldnt mind having it again.

Pours red/orange with little white head.  Aroma is faint but has vanilla, caramel, and whiskey notes.  Taste is watery up front, goes into a woody taste with some whiskey and vanilla, and ends a bit bitter.  Not bad, but the flavor is a bit lacking.

22oz bomber.  Pours a darker clear glowing golden with a huge fluffy airy creamy cream-colored head.  Aroma of sweet honey, faded hops, vanilla, some sour grains, weak bourbon, lightly corny.  Flavor is the same, I like the aged character, big barrel, lots of vanilla, toasty honey, sweetness is tame, sort of corn like, cereal, bourbon, mash and bourbon, bit hot on the finish.  Medium bodied, very light mouth-feel, lots of carbonation, airy, sharp, too much.  Like bourbon flavored water.

Medium statured tan head with good retention and some spotty lace. Clear orange amber hued brew. Nose is slight, bourbon, honey, clay, light spiceyness and some biscuity malts. Medium bodied though sorta thin. Bourbon flavors are watery, light maltiness, wood, tannins. Dry, lightly astringent finish, watered down whisky finish. Bottle procured @statelineliquors.

Light amber-orange pour with whispy white head.  Aroma of bourbon, some crackers, flowery notes.  Flavor is kind of light, crisp, with strong vanilla and oak bourbon.  Certainly lighter bodied than most bourbon barreled beers.  Well carbonated, medium mouthfeel.  Finishes with oak and bourbon.
Orange pour with lots of shite head. slight crisp fuitiness on the initial taste. palate is of slight vanilla and just a little nit too much oak. very good and interesting beer however.

Bomber pours reddish amber with plenty off white head.  Aroma of faint caramel malts, vanilla, biscuits, floral aromatic sweetness.  Similar taste profile: starts bready with vanilla and slight caramel malt pulling through the middle, finishes dry with rye whisky.  Medium carbonation and body, fuzzy mouthfeel.  Interesting and tasty take on Dead Guy.  Unique brew, loved it.
Light copper brown with a ceamy off white head. Sweet malt and whiskey aroma. Nice mild citrus crisp whiskey and oak flavors with a creamy palate

On tap at Seraveza. Well, it may be slightly better then Dead Guy only due to less diacetyl present. The barrel seemed to contribute little except for some hot boozy fusels. Caramel up front, slightly nutty and dry, finish was rounded off with some fusels and a faint hint of oak. I think this needs longer in the barrel with more time to let the fusels subside.

Tap @ AnniBrew 2 Barrel Aged Beer Festival...  Poured orange with a slightly, off-white head.  Esters and whiskey-like grains on the nose.  Well carbonated with creamy, lactic characters and a whiskey alcohol zing.  Malty finish with overall low hop presence.  Also a bready, pastry like sweetness and maybe an orange peel fruit flavor.Earlier Rating: 6/22/2009 Total Score: 3.5Tap @ Saraveza...  Poured orange with a white head.  Aroma of yeast and biscuity malts.  Some noticeable vanilla and smoked whiskey tones, but not a strong bittering alcohol flavor as I would hope for.  Otherwise, very smooth with big malts and sweet almond and baked goodness.  A little reminder of the whiskey in the finish with a hint of smoked oak or other wood-like characters.
